courses.title: Jazz Appreciation: Jazz, American Culture, and Global Contexts
courses.description: This course introduces students to jazz music and its connections to both African-American culture and global social-historical contexts. The first half of the semester focuses on the development of jazz in the United States, surveying the rise of the music as an African-American art form over the course of the twentieth century, with attention to blues, ragtime, swing, bebop, modal jazz, free jazz, and fusion. The second half of the semester considers jazz as a transnationally circulating cultural form that is both a product of and a contributor to globalizing trends, examining jazz’s circulations and permutations in contexts ranging from 1930s Shanghai to present-day West Africa. Through this course, students will gain a familiarity with the history of jazz, some of its major innovators, and its musical characteristics. Critical and close listening will be an important aspect of this course; through in-depth audition and discussion of musical examples, students will gain aural skills that increase their appreciation and understanding of jazz music. At the same time, by examining jazz in relation to issues including race, ethnicity, political consciousness, globalization, and economics, students will develop skills in thinking critically about music’s connections to social, cultural, and historical contexts. No musical background or previous study of music is required.
courses.enrollment_requirement:

courses.learning_outcomes:
Students will:

* Gain a familiarity with jazz music and how it relates to American and global cultures
* Be able to identify, comprehend, and describe important musical characteristics of different styles of jazz, and develop close listening skills that increase their appreciation and understanding of the music
* Cultivate skills in thinking critically about music’s connections to social, cultural, and historical contexts and issues
* Acquire global perspectives on music making, and learn to situate their musical perspectives and experiences within a global context

courses.description: This course equips the students the aesthetics to consider how sound and music contribute towards the overall impact on screen production. The course will focus on the 10-year of the movies of the Marvel Studio as the model, which is typical 21st Century Hollywood style, to learn about the use of sound and music in motion picture and television productions; the course will explore and demonstrate sound and music integral in the creative of screen production and can significantly affect intended result. Students will be trained to have greater appreciation of the roles and functions of screen sound design, music and compositional styles; at the same time through the view of music, psychology and Sociology, to understand musical symbolism and the usage of it, as well as the social impact.

courses.title: Understanding Musicals: Broadway and Beyond
courses.description:
How does the music work in Broadway shows? How does music interact with the plot and drama? How are megamusicals like Phantom of the Opera and Les Misérables different from the other musicals? What can we listen for to enhance our appreciation for musicals? This course explores different perspectives of studying and appreciating the musical arts of the modern musical theatre, covering areas such as analyses of the musical elements, storytelling through motifs and themes, aesthetics and criticism, as well as gender issues, politics, and other realms of contextual studies. Examples will be drawn from the Broadway musicals since the 1950s, musical films, as well as examples from the western classical tradition if deemed necessary.

Active, analytical, and critical listening will be integral to understanding the materials and concepts in this class. Students are expected and encouraged to practice active listening and analysis beyond the classroom setting. No previous experience is required. This course is not for music majors.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Not for Music Majors. 
Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students are expected to:

* Describe musical events and progression in melody, harmony, texture, orchestration, and music-text relationship and critically evaluate a piece through different parameters.
* Analyze the musical languages and devices used music theatre.
* Develop skills to listen analytically to a large-scale staged music production.
* Contextualize the musicals in their political, social, and cultural environment.
* Understand the creation of unity and coherence in a piece of musical work.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Theory of Integration and Difference
Proposed by McMillin, the theory of integration and differences discusses two layers of time in a musical, namely the time of the plot progression and the time of the song and dance. Different musicals have markedly different approaches in dealing with the two layers of time, which affects their overall effectiveness storytelling.
2. Narration and Technology
This lecture discusses how development in stage technology has changed the mode of narration in musicals, and how technology is integrated with music.
3. Understanding Leitmotifs in Musicals
This lecture discusses how musical ideas symbolize different ideas and characters in a musical theatre work, and how those ideas are transformed to assist with storytelling.
4. Social Issues in Musicals
This lecture discusses how musicals interact with the society through the lenses of politics, religion, gender issues, and other phenomena, exploring the reflection of societal values as well as the art works’ attempt to change established ideas.
5. Cultural Perspectives on Musicals
This lecture explores the portrayal of different cultures through the musical theatre, and how they affect aspects of musical creation, staging, and casting in the work.
6. The Phenomenon of Megamusicals
This lecture explores the defining characteristics of megamusicals in the 80s such as Phantom of the Opera, Les Misérables, and Cats, from the gradual adaption of the “sung-through” style to the new marketing components such as TV commercials, merchandise, souvenirs, etc.
7. Musical Innovations in Music Theatre
The lecture discusses the use of innovative musical devices in musical theatre, such as pointillism in lyrics and music, minimalism, polytonality, as well as the fusion of styles such as hip-hop and metal rock in musicals.
8. Recent Development in Musicals
This lecture discusses recent developments in musicals with a focus on musicals from the 21st century, such as La La Land, Hamilton, and other local examples.

courses.title: Beethoven in China and the West
courses.description: In the West, Beethoven is widely regarded as the greatest composer in the history of music and even of mankind. The stories of Beethoven’s broken family, failed love-life, and hearing loss have enthralled Western audiences as much as the sounds of his piano sonatas, string quartets, and symphonies. When the Berlin Wall was demolished in 1989, it was accompanied by Beethoven’s “Ode to Joy.” Yet, despite Western claims to Beethoven’s universality, nowhere else in the non-Western world is Beethoven held in such esteem–except for China. Since the late (if not even early) twentieth century, Beethoven has had more admirers in China than in the West. Who exactly is this Beethoven? And how was it that he, an Austro-German composer who read into Hinduism but never (so far is as currently known) into Confucianism, became a cultural icon both for and of the Chinese? Scholars still just do not know. In this course, we will try to figure it out for ourselves. By listening to and viewing Beethoven’s masterworks and hearing/seeing them in both their original Western and Chinese contexts, we will debate what makes this one person collectively Western, Chinese, and universal (or not). In addition to listening and reading assignments, students will research an independent essay/concert review on Beethoven and his music, whether in Greater China, the West, or both. The abilities to read or hear music are not required to excel in this class.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Not for Music Majors. 
Co-requisite: UGFH1000 or UGFN1000 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Understand Beethoven’s troubled life and how he overcame obstacles to compose his music.
2. Identify Beethoven’s major compositions and their individual musical-poetical characteristics.
3. Recognize and debate the similarities and differences between the Beethoven from the West and the Beethoven in China.
4. Identify and critique biases in Western and Chinese writings on Beethoven in various periods.
5. Be able to converse knowledgeably about Beethoven as a shared topic of interest among Western and Chinese peoples, from various perspectives (ie. Mainland/HK, German/American, etc.).
6. Extrapolate beyond the case of Beethoven to recognize and discuss other artistic and socio-political transfers between the West and China.
courses.course_syllabus:
Core content:

An Overview History of Western Classical Music in China (from before, to, and after Beethoven)
topics include the first Western composer in China, Teodorico Pedrini

Beethoven in Film and Documentary
topics include comparing representations of Beethoven in Austro-Germanic, American, and Chinese films

Beethoven in Visual Art
topics include how painters, sculptors, and minters portray Beethoven (and his look-alikes) in China and the West

Beethoven in Performance (by Western and Chinese virtuosi)
topics include whether or not race impacts how Beethoven’s music sells

Beethoven’s Life and Works, as Told in the West and in China
topics include how Beethoven’s biography has changed in the West and remained ‘romantic’ in present-day China

Beethoven’s “Heroic” Third Symphony
topics include the original political significance of this masterwork and how it changes/remains constant in China’s different political framework.

Beethoven’s opera “Fidelio”
topics include prison breaks in politcal operas and how Beethoven’s ‘money’ aria was interpreted in 1950s China

Beethoven’s “Ode to Joy” Ninth Symphony
topics include Beethoven’s reading of Orientalist writings as he created this ‘universal’ symphony

Biased or Unbiased? The Book “Beethoven in China: How the Great Composer became an Icon in the People’s Republic”
topics include the migration of Chinese Western classical musicians and their biases for/against China

Beethoven in Politics and Protests
topics include the fall of the Berlin Wall, Brexit, Tiananmen Square, and Hong Kong protests

New Chinese-Western Music Inspired by Beethoven
topics include Tan Dun and other Chinese composers’ indebtedness to Beethoven.

Selected topics:

Will Beethoven always have “Chinese Characteristics?”
topics include speculation on China’s artist and socio-economic development.

Beethoven in Popular Culture
topics include caricature, rock n roll, rap, and other popular representations of Beethoven

Beethoven and the Environment
topics include Beethoven’s role in pollution reduction and agriculture.

courses.description: This course is designed to develop the student's ability to analyze and critically evaluate arguments from a logical point of view. It will provide students with a basic understanding of such concepts as reasons, implication, validity, and fallacies. Students will learn the logical principles of deductive and inductive inferences and the techniques of applying them for determining the validity of arguments. Elements of good reasoning from an informal perspective will also be covered.

4. Translate arguments in ordinary language into symbolic argument forms.

5. Recognize common valid argument forms.

6. Identify, classify, and assess arguments in various contexts.

7. Identify and analyze informal fallacies.

courses.description:
This course is designed to develop the student's ability to analyze and critically evaluate arguments from a logical point of view. It will provide students with a basic understanding of such concepts as reasons, implication, validity, and fallacies. Students will learn the logical principles of deductive and inductive inferences and the techniques of applying them for determining the validity of arguments. Elements of good reasoning from an informal perspective will also be covered.

\* This course has tutorial teaching, but topics are the same as in UGED1111.

courses.description:
(UGED1146 is double-coded with CLCE1103.)

This is a knowledge-based course introducing Chinese language and culture. The course is designed for CUHK students (both native and non-native Chinese) who are interested in Chinese language and culture; Contents included theories and applications concerning Chinese language and culture; theories, practices and situations of teaching and learning Chinese as a second language (including Putonghua and Cantonese learning); the importance of culture in Chinese as a second language; and the language policies and its use in Hong Kong and in Mainland China.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
UGED1146 is double-coded with CLCE1103. Not for Chinese Language and Literature; CLED Majors and students who have taken CCSS1010, CLCE1103 or UGED2760. 
Co-requisite: UGFH1000 or UGFN1000 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students are expected to:

1. acquire some basic knowledge about Chinese language varieties and recognize their relationship to Chinese culture.

2. be able to develop critical mind in evaluating and appreciating Chinese language and its associated cultures.

3. be able to understand major discourses about language situations and related cultural issues in Hong Kong and in Mainland China.

4. be able to discuss some foundation theories and practices in teaching and learning Chinese as a second language.
courses.course_syllabus:
* *(A) Major Topics**

1. Understanding Chinese language and culture (introduce the relationship between language and culture with specific reference to Chinese language varieties)

2. Language in communication: the learning process (introduce key concepts and development of teaching and learning Chinese as a second/foreign language [CSL]; discuss basic principles in CSL)

3. Standard Chinese and varieties: a diachronic approach (discuss language policy of Mainland China; development of Mandarin Chinese in Mainland China; development of pinyin system and Chinese scripts)

4. Standard Chinese and varieties: a synchronic approach (discuss different Chinese varieties used in different parts of Mainland China as well as in different parts of the world)

5. Languages and cultures in Hong Kong (discuss language policy of Hong Kong; status of different languages in Hong Kong; sociolinguistic issues in Hong Kong)

6. Cantonese and other major dialects in China (discuss Cantonese and its relationship with other major dialects in China and in Hong Kong)

7. Learning Chinese: listening and speaking (introduce basic principles in teaching and learning Chinese focusing on teaching and learning listening and speaking skills with reference to linguistics, pragmatic and cultural aspects)

8. Learning Chinese: reading and writing (introduce basic principles in teaching and learning Chinese focusing on teaching and learning reading and writing skills with reference to linguistics, pragmatic and cultural aspects)

9. Appreciating language through culture (discuss Chinese varieties appearing in culture artifacts)

10. Appreciating culture through language (discuss culturally loaded idioms, proverbs, and stories; and drawn relationship between Chinese culture and language)

11. Wrap up and review of major concepts

courses.description: This course aims to provide an opportunity for students to understand the intellectual history of China from the late Qing dynasty to contemporary China. It will discuss the impact of Western ideologies on Chinese culture, as well as evaluate how they influenced Chinese intellectuals and modern Chinese society. This course integrates SDGs by discussing how western education influenced modern China. (SDG#4 Quality Education) How the contemporary Chinese intellectual tried to eliminate inequality and poverty by introducing education and new ideologies from the West. (SDG#1 No Poverty) Poverty, the developments of quality education and women rights in modern China will be examined. (SDG#10 Reduced Inequality SDG#16 Peace and Justice Strong Institutions) Students are able to exam several modern China SDGs developments through historical aspects, including SDG#1 No Poverty SDG#4 Quality Education SDG#10 Reduced Inequality SDG#16 Peace and Justice Strong Institutions.

courses.subject: UGED
courses.title: The Successful Self
courses.description:
Success is defined as the accomplishment of an aim or purpose. This definition implies that successful individuals engage in purposeful, agentic pursuits. Success in attaining task goals confers a feeling of competence; success in reaching relationship goals gives one a feeling of acceptance. Both feelings are major ingredients of mental health.

Success in attaining valued goals requires the abilities to adapt to change. These abilities include openness to diverse ideas, cognitive flexibility, creativity, emotional stability, motivation and perseverance. Behavioural research has shown that success is more likely among people who possess several self-attributes. In this course, we will empower students with theoretical and empirical knowledge of these attributes, and engage them in weekly experiential activities, through which they will develop and weave these self-attributes into their daily goal pursuits. Through the use of a self-assessment online platform, student will track their personal growth in these self-attributes.

Major aspects of the successful self that will be covered in this course are: the rational self, veridical self-knowledge, the transcendent self, the socially intelligent self, the loved self, the multicultural self, and the global self.

This course is closely related to the SDG subgoal of promoting mental health and well-being. First, psychological well-being ensues from attaining one's valued goals. In addition, feeling competent and feeling accepted are two pillars of psychological maturity and mental health. In this course, students will learn the concepts and practical skills that would enable students to more effectively attain their valued goal, and feel competent and accepted.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Not for Psychology Majors. 
Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students who complete this course are expected to be able to

1. Understand the key factors that contribute to a successful self (LO1)

2. Critically evaluate the empirical evidence for major theories of successful self (LO2)

3. Apply evidence-based theories of successful self to self-improvement (LO3)

4. Track their changes in pertinent self-attributes through experiential learning and longitudinal measures of these attributes (LO4)

Topic 1: Adaptive intelligence: The ability of the mind to be able to change in response to the current demand in the environment

Topic 2: The irrational self: People are predictably irrational

Topic 3: The perils of addiction to self-esteem: Narcissistic people are emotionally unstable and socially hostile

Topic 4: Defensive pessimism: The emotional price people pay for their desire for performance

Topic 9: The loved self: When waiting for Mr./Ms. Right is not right

Topic 10: The multicultural self: How multicultural experiences increase your flexibility and creativity

Topic 11: The global self**: How having a global mindset increases performance in the global era**

courses.subject: UGED
courses.title: World Religions
courses.description:
(UGED1400 is double-coded with CURE1123.)

This course provides an introduction to some major religious traditions in the world from a phenomenological and historical point of view. Topics include Christianity, Judaism, Islam, Hinduism, Buddhism, Confucianism, Daoism and Local religions etc.. Through the study of religion in different cultures, this course seeks to broaden students' horizons and widen their academic experience.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
UGED1400 is double-coded with CURE1123. 
Not for Cultural Studies; Public Humanities; Religious Studies; Theology Majors; and students who have taken CURE1123. 
Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
courses.learning_outcomes:
Knowledge Outcomes:

(1) Students will be able to understand world religions in their historical settings and contemporary contexts of modern living; globally, locally and in their many facets

* (2) Students will be able to engage in a* critical analysis of religions by the methods of the humanities and social sciences

Skill Outcomes

(1) Students will be able to develop their skills associated with data gathering and direct observation; organizing it, understanding it, and presenting it.

(2) Students will be able to develop their skills in cross-cultural understanding and intercultural literacy.

Attitude Outcomes

(1) Students will be able to develop their ability to have a critical and yet sympathetic understanding and appreciation of religious traditions especially those one does not belong

(2) Students will be able to develop their sensitivity to ultimate concern and religious dimension of human life

courses.subject: UGED
courses.title: Study of Christianity
courses.description:
(UGED1520 is double-coded with CURE1124.)

The primary aim of this course is to provide students a broad and comprehensive understanding of the Christian faith through introducing its characteristics, traditions, history, scripture, theology and ethics. It helps students to analyse critically the various forms of Christianity and appreciate the richness of the Christian religion that exerts so great influences on human civilizations. Through interdisciplinary dialogues, this course also aims at helping students to see how the Christian faith understands and deals with problems, predicaments, political and ethical dilemmas of humanity.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
UGED1520 is double-coded with CURE1124. 
Not for Cultural Studies; Public Humanities; Religious Studies; Theology Majors; and students who have taken CURE1124. 
Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
courses.learning_outcomes:
Knowledge:

* To achieve proper understanding of Christianity as a global phenomenon and some of the representative manifestations of Christianity in various local contexts.
* To obtain a comprehensive knowledge of the major aspects of Christian faith, especially its views of the meaning of human life.
* To have a basic understanding of the methodology involved in the multidisciplinary study of Christianity.

Skills:

* To be able to use the analytical framework and hermeneutical tools for the academic studies of the religious phenomena related to Christianity.
* To be capable of relating what have been leant from this course to some other academic disciplines.
* To have the ability to reflect critically on one’s own cultural and / or religious tradition.

Attitudes:

* To treasure the value of human life and be sensitive to the related ethical responsibilities.
* To appreciate the diversity within particular cultural and / religious tradition.
* To become more respectful to others’ religions, worldviews and values.

courses.subject: UGED
courses.title: Mathematics in Visual Art
courses.description: This course aims to help students appreciate the role which mathematics plays in the development of Western visual art, discern mathematical elements in visual artworks, and reflect on the oft-held belief that there exists an impassable gulf between art and science. Topics include: the role which mathematics plays in Greco-Roman aesthetic theories, the mathematical basis of linear perspective in painting, the mathematics behind different models in color theory, planar symmetries in visual art and their connection to group theory, and mathematical methods in the analysis of artworks.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for MATH; MIEG; BMED; and students in the concen. areas of Nat Sci Pro: Data Sci; or Math Sci, .  Co-requisite: UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or 1001 (only applicable to students admitted to 4-year curriculum)
courses.learning_outcomes:
The ultimate goal is the acquisition of an intellectual schema upon which analysis and evaluation may be made regarding multiple aspects of visual art and mathematics, both within the scope of the course and beyond. Specific learning outcomes are as follows:

1. Identify the historical background, prominent aesthetic components, and mathematical elements in specific examples of artwork.
2. Comprehend the mathematical ideas (e.g. linear perspective, group theory) present in a range of artwork.
3. Recognize and analyze mathematical elements in artworks, and conversely connections to art in mathematical ideas.
4. Acquire a rudimentary knowledge of artistic and mathematical vocabulary which could then be applied to discuss (both orally and in writing) ideas presented in the course.
5. Appreciate the mutual flows of application and inspiration which exist between mathematics and visual art.
6. Acquire hands-on experience in:

* traditional drawing techniques such as the use of proportional measurements and triangulation.
* the depiction of space and form using linear perspective.

7. Evaluate the importance of the role which mathematics plays in art, and the relevance/utility of analyzing art from a mathematical perspective.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Greco-Roman aesthetics and the art/mathematics of proportional measurement.

* Rational proportions: The Greek *Canon*, Vitruvian Man, Greco-Roman sculpture and architecture.

* Irrational proportions: The Golden Ratio in architecture and pictorial composition, myth or not?

* Measurement techniques in drawing.

1. Linear perspective in Renaissance art.

* Euclidean Geometry.

* Projective Geometry and its relation to linear perspective in painting.

* Discussion of potential conflict between aesthetics and the strict adherence to mathematical frameworks. Case study: "The Column Problem."

* Examination of specific examples of Renaissance art (Italian, Northern; Early, High).

1. Color Theory.

* Historical developments, from Plato, Goethe to Grassmann.

* Different color systems: RGB, HSV, Munsell, CYMK.

* Models of color perception: psychophysics, trichromatic theory, opponent process theory.

* Examination of artistic movements/techniques incorporating elements of modern (or close to modern) color theory: Impressionism, Pointillism, Color Field paintings.

1. Planar symmetries and group theory.

* Basic introduction to Group Theory and its relation to the symmetry of planar patterns.

* Examination of artworks: Moorish designs in Spanish architecture, works of M. C. Escher.

5. Stylometry analysis of paintings.

* Introduction to mathematical techniques used in the analysis of artworks: Fractal analysis, Geometric Tight Frame analysis.

courses.subject: UGED
courses.title: Live to Flourish: the Science and Practice of Positive Psychology
courses.description: Research over the last couple of decades sheds light on the role of positive emotions and cognitions in our psychological functioning. Empirical evidence shows that people who harbour positive emotions achieve better life outcomes, which include, but not limited to, physical and mental health, work performance, supportive relationships, and effective coping. This Course is designed to provide students with the latest scientific knowledge on the development of positive psychology as well as its applications. Students will not only learn practical behavioural, cognitive and social skills that enhance their positive emotions and thus resilience and strength, they will also learn to identify and leverage their own virtues and strengths in their daily life. All of which are part of the essential life skills that not only build resilience and strength, but also the confidence and flexibility required of our young men and women to rise above the challenges they face nowadays, and lead a flourishing and meaningful life.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Not for Psychology Majors. 
Co-requisite: UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or UGFN1001 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of this course, students should be able to:

* Acquire knowledge on the scientific foundation of positive psychology and what makes people flourish in multiple ways
* Identify and leverage their own character strengths for building self-esteem and seeking meaning in life
* Develop practices that lead to positive emotions and build them into habits to develop strengths and resilience
* Increase mental agility to think flexibly, realistically and accurately for problem-solving
* Apply empirically validated interpersonal skills for positive social relationship in daily life
courses.course_syllabus:
* *Lesson 1: Introduction to Positive Psychology (2 hours)**

* Understanding the science of positive psychology and its applications

* *Lesson 2: Understanding The Positive Self (2 hours)**

* Learning about Character Strengths and Virtues

* Identifying and utilizing one’s own strengths

* *Lesson 3: Building Healthy Lifestyle (2 hours)**

* Understanding basic principles of stress management

* Understanding one’s own derailers under stress

* Learning the basic principles in enhancing body well-being

* *Lesson 4-6: Developing practices for lasting effects on one’s positive emotions (6 hours)**

* Understanding the nature of positive emotions and their lasting positive effects in one’s life and work

* Developing behavioural practices in enhancing one’s emotional well-being

+ Gratitude

+ Savouring

+ Mindfulness

+ Act of Kindness

* *Lesson 7-8: Building Resilience - Basic Mood Regulation (4 hours)**

* Identifying automatic thoughts to make sense of specific emotional consequences

* Identifying hurdles in applying skills of emotional regulation –one’s own explanatory style

* Understanding the different cognitive processes between optimism and pessimism

* *Lesson 9-10: Building Resilience - Increasing Emotional Fitness (4 hours)**

* Introducing the basic principles in managing one’s negative emotion

* Learning to evaluate one’s own thoughts and putting them into perspective

* Learning to master skills of reattributing one’s thoughts on the adversities to some more accurate causal sources

* *Lesson 11-13: Positive Interpersonal Relationship - Increasing Emotional Fitness (6 hours)**

* Introducing the concept of social resilience

* Creating a new mindset of successful relationship

* Learning to increase Positive Resonance

* Learning to master skills of creating alliance and handling conflicts

courses.title: Positive Psychology in Everyday Life
courses.description:
(UGED1554 is double-coded with PSYC1020.)
Positive psychology is the scientific study of positive influences in life, namely, positive subjective experiences, positive individual traits, and positive institutions that enhance our quality of life and avert pathologies in time of adversities. This is a knowledge-based course introducing the basic concepts of positive psychology and its application in daily life. This course aims at inspiring students’ interest and self-reflection in positive psychology, as well as the healthy mindsets and lifestyles that it espouses, while encouraging students to plan and initiate habit changes via the integration of positive psychology in their daily lives.

* Understand the scientific foundation of positive psychology
* Recognize the empirically validated practices that enhance individual well-being
* Obtain knowledge about the real life applications of positive psychology in different settings, e.g., educational and business organizations
* Reflect on personal experiences using positive psychological concepts
* Plan self-improvement habit changes via integration of positive psychology in their daily lives

courses.description:
(UGED1600 is double-coded with SOWK1150.)

This course adopts a humanistic approach to personal growth. It aims at facilitating students to achieve better self-understanding and self-confidence, expand options in life and develop greater self-acceptance. Through classroom instruction and small group experiential learning, students will be guided to review their personal growth and development, to examine issues and choices in significant aspects of their lives, and to reflect on their values and attitudes. Major topics covered include human development, family and relationships, love and sexuality, health and wellness, society and social responsibility, study and career, and death and loss.

courses.subject: UGED
courses.title: Living with Grief: Understanding Death, Dying and Bereavement
courses.description:
(UGED1602 is double-coded with SOWK1130.)

Death is not special. It happens every day and everywhere. It is also an inevitable part of life. Yet, death is very important for us especially when we are confronted by the death and dying of our loved ones. Surprisingly, we have done little to prepare ourselves to get familiar with the topic of bereavement. Very often we learn it only from the most painful and heartbreaking moments in life—after the death of loved ones. While bereavement may induce us different grief reactions, and adjustment difficulties, it also provides an opportunity for us to experience personal growth, reflect on our values and search for the meaning in life.

As a result, this course aims to prepare students to face death, dying and bereavement that they may encounter in their life. In particular, they are facilitated to respond to a unique question, “How can I live with the grief?” This question can only be answered by the students themselves who will have an opportunity to understand more about death, dying and bereavement, as well as reflecting on their life and living through this course.

courses.course_syllabus:
1. Basic knowledge on death and dying:

a. concepts of good death,

b. attitudes towards death, e.g. death anxiety, death acceptance

c. the dying process,

d. adjustment to anticipatory grief

2. Basic knowledge on bereavement,

a. grief reactions

b. grief processes and theories, e.g. Dual Process Model

c. specific types of bereavement, e.g. suicidal bereavement, men’s grief, elderly grief, children’s grief, etc.

d. adjustment bereavement, and living with grief

3. Values, life priorities and meaning in life

a. Existential perspective on life, death and bereavement

b. Search for meaning in life following bereavement (e.g. Vitkor Frankl’s logotherapeutic perspective)

courses.subject: UGED
courses.title: Movies, Life and Social Work
courses.description:
(UGED1651 is double-coded with SOWK1160.)

This course is designed to examine human life issues through movie watching. A social work perspective and a humanistic outlook of life will be adopted to view human lives at individual, family and society levels. Students are expected to develop an awareness and a sense of concern for people and the society. Movies related to social work values, such as people's capacity for change, respect for human worth and dignity, and social justice will be reviewed and discussed. Social issues, such as discrimination, mental illness and issue of oppression will also be covered.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
UGED1651 is double-coded with SOWK1160. 
Not for Social Work Majors; and students who have taken SOWK1160. 
Co-requisite: UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or UGFN1001 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction: Essence of social work practice; what can be offered by movies (entertainment, knowing about the world around, thought-inspiration) – how movies reflect on human lives and social conditions.

2. Connecting to humanity in movies: The “Humanistic” view of human being –

* a genuine concern for people’s lives
* a high respect for human value
* a loving heart for touching with human sufferings and people’s struggles, etc.

3. The “Psychoanalytic” view of human being -

* structure of personality, how it differs from the humanistic view
* conscious & unconscious in relating to human behaviours
* service gaps in working with people having mental health problems

4. Today’s Youngsters: At the Crossroad – a) “Behavioural” view of human being; and b) ‘Cognitive-behavioural” view

* the importance of environment in shaping behaviours of human
* familial, social and personal issues faced by our young generations
* youth service in Hong Kong

5. Love Relationships

* Essence of Love Affairs/Romantic Relationships
* Common issues encountered by social workers, e.g. Extra-marital affairs

6. Fight for justice

* what is justice and injustice
* standing for justice
* social advocacy for justice

7. Poverty

* a big gap between the rich & the poor
* social measures to reduce poverty

8. Lonely elderly?

* needs of elderly
* to concern for the well-being of our elderly
* elderly service in Hong Kong

9. Treasure the Family

* common issues in family
* dealing with communication barriers

10. Sexual discrimination in society

* homosexuality as a social issue
* our attitudes towards sexual orientation

11. Getting Free from Stress & Anxiety/Take good care of our mental health

* sources of stress
* effects of stress
* coping well with stress

12. Life is what we make of it

* how we perceive life and cope with human adversity
* people can enjoy life when they encounter difficulties and hardships

courses.subject: UGED
courses.title: Issues of Political Philosophy
courses.description:
(UGED1660 is double-coded with GPAD1095.)

This course will introduce students to key issues of political philosophy, including political authority and obligation, democracy, social justice, and freedom and right, through conceptual analysis and rational assessment of the thought of major political philosophers.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
UGED1660 is double-coded with GPAD1095. 
Not for Government and Public Administration Majors; and students who have taken GPAD1095.
Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
courses.learning_outcomes:
* *Aims**

◊To foster critical understanding of a range of fundamental issues and concepts of political philosophy.

◊To foster interest in the history of western political thought.

◊To foster the ability to analyze and assess opposing arguments in political philosophy.

◊To foster appreciation of the relevance of political philosophy to contemporary political and social issues.

◊To foster the ability to read classics of political philosophy.

* *Objectives**

After taking this course, students are expected to be able to: -

◊have general understanding of the major development of western political thought.

◊grasp the basic concepts of political philosophy.

◊comprehend and critically analyze complex philosophical arguments.

◊learn how to write academic essays.

◊construct sustained arguments about major political theories, and apply them to the analysis of public affairs.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction: What is Political Philosophy? (導論：何謂政治哲學？)

2. State and its Authority (國家及其權威)

3. Man as Political Animal: Aristotle’s Political Thought

作為政治的動物：亞里士多德的政治思想

4. Social Contract Theory I: Hobbes

社會契約論I：霍布士

5. Social Contract Theory II: John Locke & Rousseau

社會契約論II：洛克及盧梭

6. Social Contract Theory III: Rousseau

社會契約論III：盧梭

7. Democracy (民主) I

8. Democracy (民主) II

9. Liberty I: Concepts of Liberty (自由的概念)

10. Liberty II: Value of Liberty (自由的價值)

11. Justice (公正)

12. Right (權利)

13. Equality (平等)

courses.description:
(UGED1796 is double-coded with EPIN1010.)

This course is an introduction to the mindset and values of an entrepreneur. The primary objective is to make students appreciate and adapt to change in the world of entrepreneurship. Whether a student takes the entrepreneurial path or chooses to become a manager in the corporate world upon graduation, the entrepreneurial spirit as inspired by the journey of a successful entrepreneur will help produce out-of-the-box ideas and the ability to cope with challenges in the business world.

In this course, prominent figures and seasoned entrepreneurs will be invited to share their real stories and experiences regarding creativity, innovation, problem-solving and entrepreneurship in different situations. As “fail early fail fast” has become the unofficial mantra in the Silicon, guest speakers are encouraged to give an honest account of their devastating failures and reveal how they survive, adapt, and achieve eventual success.

courses.title: Philosophy as a Way of Life
courses.description: This course guides students to think about the ultimate practical question—How should we live?—from the perspectives of ancient Greek and Roman philosophers, such as Plato, Aristotle, the Stoics, and Epicurus. Their profound reflections on the ways of life have produced a variety of proposals for how one should live. This course will look at and examine the thoughts on which these proposals are based, as well as the responses of critics at their time and modern-day assessments. Students will understand and reflect philosophically on such ethical concepts as excellence, virtue, and happiness. They will also learn to appreciate how these various proposals can make a distinctive and practical contribution to their search for a good life.

courses.title: Invitation to Linguistics
courses.description:
(UGED1924 is double-coded with LING1000.)
This course invites students to explore the central components of human language, examining its structure and functions, how it is acquired, and how it changes over time. Students will have an overview of the grammatical properties of language, with respect to its sounds and sound system (phonetics and phonology), words and word formation (morphology), sentence patterns (syntax), and meaning (semantics). The course will highlight the psychological and biological foundations of language, and the applications of linguistics to other fields. Students will develop a basic understanding of language as a computational system that interacts with other cognitive systems of the human brain.

The course will also discuss the social aspects of language and the computational processing of human language. Students will become more sensitive to their own use of language, and develop an appreciation of recent advances in linguistic science, with respect to universals and particulars of language, language and society, language variation and change, language acquisition, as well as language, mind and the brain.

courses.title: Understanding Hearing Loss
courses.description:
This course examines the challenges and issues faced by Deaf and hard-of-hearing (D/HH) individuals when they attempt to adapt themselves to the teaching and learning practices and communication styles in a mainstream postsecondary educational context. This adaptation is particularly challenging when these variables could be fundamentally different from their previous learning experiences. For instance, they may encounter difficulties when they participate in lectures, tutorial or group discussions, presentations, lab work,...etc. resulting in communication barriers and social alienation.

Within UN’s SDG Framework, the course enables students to achieve a general understanding of the nature and causes of hearing loss (SDG #3: Good Health and Well-Being), and how to reduce communication barriers while dispelling misconceptions and negative attitudes towards D/HH individuals (SDG #10: Reduced Inequalities). Additionally, the course examines how the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities (CRPD) tackles issues relating to deafness, sign language, Deaf communication, and information accessibility in education and public domains. Students will analyze the economic, social, and environmental challenges faced by D/HH communities, such as limited access to healthcare, education, and employment. These challenges are explored in the context of how they perpetuate inequality and restrict opportunities for D/HH individuals (SDG #16: Peace, Justice and Strong Institutions). At a broader level, the course underlies the impact of communication barriers on the quality of life and opportunities available to D/HH individuals. It also emphasizes the circumstances within a mainstream postsecondary educational context, D/HH individuals can be afforded equal opportunities and appropriate support to achieve quality education. (SDG #4: Quality Education).

This course contains 7 themes each of which is packaged with a set of pre-recorded lectures and micromodules supplemented with multimedia resources such as YouTubes, Ted talks, DHH sharings and Deaf documentaries.

* Acquire some basic skills and strategies to interact with D/HH individuals, reducing inequality in information accessibility and education. (SDG #10: Reduced Inequalities).

courses.title: Understanding Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder and Neurodiversity
courses.description: Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) is one of the most common neurodiverse conditions in society. This course will introduce different perspectives to understand ADHD and analyze issues concerning this community. This course will present the characteristics of individuals with ADHD, use different theoretical frameworks to understand this type of human differences, and suggest implications for students' development and well-being (SDG#3 Good Health and Well-being).This course aims at developing heightened awareness and practical strategies that can support the learning and developmental needs of neurodivergent learners, and support students to effectively interact with peers with ADHD in campus (SDG#4 Quality Education). It also discusses how the interaction of neurobiological differences and the social environment and systems may differentially impact the functioning and well-being of individuals with ADHD, and how to advocate better supports for them in the community (SDG#10 Reduced Inequalities).

courses.course_syllabus:
1. Overview of ADHD

a. This lesson gives basic introduction to the traditional clinical definitions of ADHD and clarify common myths and facts about ADHD (e.g., etiology, prevalence, biological bases, identification methods).

2. Perspectives in understanding ADHD

a. This lesson presents different models to understand ADHD as individual differences, including medical model, social model, and neurodiversity paradigm.

3. Executive Functioning (I)

a. Lessons 3 to 7 focus on different aspects of characteristic and challenges associated with ADHD in university students. Lesson 3 focuses on issues around attention (e.g., attention span, switch, selective attention, sustained attention), memory, and overactivity.

4. Executive Functioning (II)

a. Lesson 4 focuses on higher-order executive functioning aspects, such as task organization/planning/initiation, time management, and metacognitive abilities.

5. Emotion regulation

a. Lesson 5 focuses on the common emotional challenges experienced by individuals with ADHD and comorbid mental health conditions.

6. Social communication

a. Lesson 6 focuses on the common challenges in social communication and relationships associated with ADHD.

7. ADHD across ages and genders

a. Lesson 7 introduces on age and gender differences in ADHD, with a focus on intersectionality and diverse presentations of ADHD.

8. Best practices for supporting university students with ADHD (I)

a. Lesson 8 introduces best-practice support strategies that can be implemented at individual level to directly support university students with ADHD (e.g., medication, accommodations, behavioral management and coaching, cognitive-behavioral techniques).

9. Best practices for supporting university students with ADHD (II)

a. Lesson 9 introduces best-practice systems-level approaches that can be used to tailor a better environment for university students with ADHD (e.g., classroom teaching/learning strategies, accommodations, interdisciplinary professional support, peer mentoring).

10. Employment and workplace issues

a. Lesson 10 introduces ideas of career exploration and development for individuals with ADHD. It covers common challenges experienced by individuals with ADHD in the workplace and effective strategies/accommodations.

11. Supporting families

a. Lesson 11 introduces a family-centered perspective to supporting individuals with ADHD and their family members (e.g., parents, siblings).

12. ADHD in the community

a. Lesson 12 focuses on how the local community understands and treats individuals with ADHD, which will cover issues such as social inclusion, stigma, media representations, etc.

13. Conclusion & final exam

a. This lesson summarizes what students would have learnt and their knowledge about the course will be tested by final exam.

courses.title: Understanding Neurodiverse Condition – Autism
courses.description: Autism is one of the most common neurodiverse conditions in society. This course will introduce different theoretical frameworks to understand autism and analyze issues concerning this community. This course will present the characteristics of autistic individuals and the challenges they may have in learning and communicating with others. It will also discuss practices that can support and interact with autistic individuals in academic, workplace, and social settings. This course aims at developing heightened awareness and sensitivity towards neurodivergent learners and encouraging students to effectively interact with peers with autism in and outside campus, subsequently creating an inclusive society and learning environment on campus and achieving SDG#3 (Good Health and Well-Being) and SDG#10 (Reduced Inequalities).

9 Women on autism (This lesson describes the unique autism characteristics found in autistic women)

courses.subject: UGED
courses.title: Selected Readings: Pre-Qin Legalist texts
courses.description: Legalism is one of the most important Pre-Qin schools of thought. It has a significant impact on Chinese culture. By examining selected Legalist texts, this course aims at illustrating the major doctrines and development of Legalism, as well as its influence on Chinese culture.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Not for Chinese Language and Literature; and Chinese Language Studies and Chinese Language Education (CLED) Majors.
Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
courses.learning_outcomes:
預期修畢本科後，學員能够：

1. 概括先秦法家學說之內容特質。

2. 分析法家學說在先秦時期之作用。

3. 了解先秦法家對中國文化之影響。

Upon completion of this module, students should be able to:

1. master special features of Pre-Qin Legalism.

2. analyze the usage of Legalism during Pre-Qin Dynasty.

3. comprehend the influence of Pre-Qin Legalism in Chinese culture.
courses.course_syllabus:
科目內容

一、先秦法家思想的淵源與時代背景

1. 法家出於理官

2. 法家本於黃老之學

3. 春秋戰國時期的時代背景

二、先秦法家思想的發展

1. 春秋時期

2. 戰國時期

3. 秦統一時期

三、先秦法家人物生平概論

1. 慎到

2. 申不害

3. 商鞅

4. 韓非子

四、先秦法家文獻選讀

1. 重勢派．慎到

2. 重術派．申不害

3. 重法派．商鞅

4. 集大成．韓非子

五、先秦法家對中國文化的影響

1. 政治

2. 刑法制度

3. 學術思想

六、先秦法家思想的現代價值

1. 法制與法治

2. 領導管理

Module Content:

1. The origins and background of Pre-Qin Legalism

2. Introduction of Key Pre-Qin Legalists

3. The development of Pre-Qin Legalism

4. Selected Readings (Shen Dao, Shen Buhai, Shang Yang, Hanfeizi)

5. The influence of Pre-Qin legalism on Chinese Culture

6. The Value of Pre-Qin Legalism in Modern Times

courses.subject: UGED
courses.title: Taiwan Literature Appreciation
courses.description: This course provides an introduction to the historical background, genres, significant writers and texts of Taiwan Literature. Students are expected to understand Taiwan Literature from artistic, political and cultural perspectives, and to master the methodologies of literary criticism by reading selected texts of Taiwan Literature.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Not for Chinese Language and Literature; and Chinese Language Studies and Chinese Language Education (CLED) Majors.
Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
courses.learning_outcomes:
預期修畢本科目，學生能夠：

1. 認識臺灣文學的代表作家及作品

2. 掌握分析臺灣文學作品的方法

3. 透過閱讀臺灣文學作品，反思臺灣的歷史、文化和政治等議題

4. 增加閱讀臺灣文學的興趣。

Upon completion of this module, students shoule be able:

1. To appreciate the artistry of key Taiwan writers and their works.

2. To master the methodology of analyzing Taiwan Literature.

3. To re-consider the history, culture and politics of Taiwan Literature through reading selected texts.

4. To be better prepared for immersing themselves in Taiwan Literature.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. 臺灣文學的發展概況

從臺灣歷史說起：臺灣原住民、荷蘭殖民時期、鄭成功在臺灣

2. 臺灣文學中不同文類的藝術特色

現代主義小說、圖象詩、現代散文等

王德威從文學角度看歷史、史書美的華語語系研究、陳芳明的臺灣新文學史

Poetry : Hsia Yu, Chen Li

Prose: Yu Kwang-chung *Ghost Rain*, Lin Wen-Yueh *People Who Studied Chinese Language and Literature*, Luo Yi-jun *Little Son*

4. Criticism on Taiwan Literature

A History through Literature(David Wang), Sinophone Studies(**Shih Shu-mei)****,** A History of Modern Taiwanese Literature (Chen Fang-ming)

5. Relationship of Taiwan, Hong Kong and Mainland China Literature

《The Inspired Island‧The Untrammeled Traveler》

courses.subject: UGED
courses.title: Culture and Art of Chinese Couplets
courses.description: Couplet is a unique form of literary writing in Chinese. Often found on display at ancient and scenic sites, in palaces and temples, in stores and private residences, couplets are an integral part of the Chinese cultural life. They are composed to mark various social occasions, festive and sad, including birthday and wedding celebrations as well as funeral mournings. This course will provide a close examination of the couplet, its writing and appreciation, and to make use of this literary genre as a window to the greater cultural tradition in China. The class will include practical exercises designed to help students acquire not only an ability to appreciate but also actual skills in composing couplets.

courses.subject: UGED
courses.title: Music in Film
courses.description: This course examines the role of music and sound in film. It enables students with no training in music or media studies to better appreciate the art of film music.Through lectures and assignments that comprise viewing, listening, and reading, students explore the work of many composers and directors and gain skills to critically evaluate what they see and hear.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Not for Music Majors.
Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
courses.learning_outcomes:
Through this course, students will have:

* Expanded their knowledge of film and music, and acquired a broad appreciation of the methods of film composers
* Developed an understanding of how music and other sounds interact with visual images to communicate ideas
* Enhanced their critical skills and developed the habit of questioning the meaning of what they see and hear
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction
Overview of the course, objectives, introduction to the study of film music. Recommended readings cover elements of film and music.
2. The language of film music
Terminology – purely musical elements: dissonance, major-minor, style topics, timbre, atonality, music in the film context: diegetic & non-diegetic, acoustics, audio dissolve; synchronization, counterpoint, clarity and false clarity, presence of absence, structural use of music, the montage and performance scenes.
3. Post-WWII science fiction and the sound of technology
The place of timbre in sci-fi films of the 1940s and ‘50s, focusing on the introduction of electronic sound in films such as *The Day the Earth Stood Still* and *Forbidden Planet*
4. Vangelis and the sound of technology in the 1980s
Composer Vangelis’s use of synthesizers in films of the 1980s and ‘90s, including action films (*Missing*), historical drama (*Chariots of Fire*), and the classic genre-blending sci-fi, *Blade Runner*.
5. Rachel Portman and the sound of tradition
Scores from the English film composer Rachael Portman, best known for her work on literary and historical dramas, such as *Chocolat*, *Cider House Rules*, *Emma*, *Never Let Me Go*, and *One Day*
6. Bernard Herrmann: master film composer
Broad overview of one of the most successful film composers of the post-WWII era. Examples include excerpts from *Citizen Kane*, *The Ghost and Mrs. Muir*, several of his scores for Alfred Hitchcock (*Vertigo*, *Psycho*, *North By Northwest*), and his final score, for Martin Scorsese’s *Taxi Driver* (1976)
7. Ennio Morricone: spaghetti westerns and more
One of the most original film composers: Ennio Morricone. Examples drawn from his classic 1960s spaghetti westerns of Sergio Leone (*Once Upon a Time in the West*), to big-budget Hollywood (*The Mission*, *The Legend of 1900*) and European films (*Malèna*, *Cinema Paradiso*)
8. Zhao Jiping (and Zhang Yimou)
Politics and culture: classic Chinese films of the 1980s and ‘90s, including *Red Sorghum* and *Raise the Red Lantern*
9. Stanley Kubrick and classical music
A filmmaker known for his borrowing from classical music for the soundtracks of his films. Examples from historical dramas (*Barry Lyndon*), war films (Full Metal Jacket), classic horror (*The Shining*), science fiction (*2001, A Space Odyssey*), and his final film (*Eyes Wide Shut*)
10. The pop compilation soundtrack
For several decades popular music has provided the readymade soundtracks – from such classics of the 1960s as *The Graduate* and *Easy Rider* to the more obscure uses of pop music in the films of Quentin Tarantino (*Pulp Fiction*, *Kill Bill*).
11. Ang Lee and the period drama
Wide-ranging work of Taiwanese-US director, focusing on the use of music in period dramas: *The Ice Storm* (1997), *Brokeback Mountain* (2005), and *Lust, Caution* (2007)
12. Comedy: the sound of humour and Course overview
The course ends with a lecture on music in comedy films – from early animation and the films of Charlie Chaplin to the works of and Stephen Chow (周星馳).

courses.subject: UGED
courses.title: Existentialism and Literature
courses.description:
(UGED2172 is double-coded with ENGE2220.)
This course looks at the close relationship between existentialist philosophy and literature. Existentialism is a philosophical movement that focuses on human existence and the challenges of choice, freedom, and responsibility in the modern world. We will explore a variety of existentialist positions—including those of Kierkegaard, Nietzsche, Heidegger, Sartre, and de Beauvoir—to understand how existentialist thought constitutes an important intellectual context for many themes in modern literature, including authenticity, alienation, and anxiety. Authors to be discussed include Kafka, Dostoevsky, Ionesco, Camus, Beckett and others. Students interested in literary representations of the existential challenges of the human condition are welcome to attend this course.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
UGED2172 is double-coded with ENGE2220. 
Not for English; English Studies and English Language Education (ELED) Majors; and students who have taken ENGE2220. 
Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students should be able to:

* analyze and synthesize some of the most distinct themes and concepts in the existentialist movement
* analyze and evaluate various approaches to reading existentialist themes in modern literature
* appreciate the importance, relevance, and value of existentialist themes in modern literature
* produce a well-reasoned critical essay
courses.course_syllabus:
* **Week 1**
+ Topic: Introduction (syllabus, reading material exam issues)
- Description: In this lecture, we will go through all the practical issues related to this course.

* **Week 2**
+ Topic: Introduction to Existentialism and Literature
- Description: This lecture provides a broad overview of the historical and intellectual background of existentalist literature, and some of the major ideas associated with this movement.

* **Week 3**
+ Topic: Choice and Responsibility
- Description: In Week 3, we will explore how Sartre’s notion of ‘choice’ plays a crucial role in modern literature, including *Nausea* and “Drive my Car.”

* **Week 4**
+ Topic: Freedom and Anxiety
- Description: This lecture explores the difference between ‘fear’ and ‘anxiety’, and how this difference is often thematized in modern literature and art.

* **Week 5**
+ Topic: The Ethics of Existence
- Description: This week, we explore the relationship between individual freedom and moral responsibility.

* **Week 6**
+ Topic: Alienation and Guilt
- Description: Guilt and alienation are some of the major themes in existentialist literature. This lecture explains how Kafka and Ionesco address these themes.

* **Week 7**
+ Topic: Authentic Living, Das Man, Subjects and Objects
- Description: What is meant by an ‘authentic’ life—as opposed to a life of gestures, illusions, and performances? We will explore this question through a discussion of Heidegger’s philosophy and the film *The Truman Show.*

* **Week 8**
+ Topic: The Absurd and the Meaning of Life
- Description: One of the best known existentalist writers, Albert Camus introduced the philosophy of the absurd. This lecture provides an introduction to this philosophy through a discussion of the novel *The Stranger.*

* **Week 9**
+ Topic: Repetition and the Eternal Recurrence of the Same
- Description: Nietzsche formulates a way of thinking about the repetitiveness of existence, and this lecture will apply these thoughts in connection with a discussion of the film *Groundhog Day.*

* **Week 10**
+ Topic: Language and Presence
- Description: This lecture focuses on the role of language in existentialist literature, and more specifically the gap between language and reality.
* **Week 11**
+ Topic: Waiting, Inaction, Boredom
- Description: Accompanying the sense of individual freedom, protagonists in existentialist literature often experience a sense of purposelessness. The lecture will discuss this challenge in connection with works by Beckett and Coppola.
* **Week 12**
+ Topic: Memory, Regret, and Existence
- Description: The course began with Sartre’s notion of choice; this penultimate lecture looks at the time when these choices have been made, and when people will have to live with these decisions.
* **Week 13**
+ Course Summary & Conclusion

courses.subject: UGED
courses.title: (How to Read) Masterpieces of Literature
courses.description:
(UGED2186 is double-coded with ENGE2130.)

Why read literature? This course offers a broad look through literary history to understand the enduring value and diversity of literature. For each lecture, we will look at a literary masterpiece — from antiquity to the present — and address three main issues: A) the work and its historical context; B) how to read it; and C) themes that make the work relevant in contemporary society and in our everyday lives. The course is designed as an introductory survey of literary works that have had a major impact throughout the ages. Issue A) is intended to give students a sense of the work’s impact in its own time; B) is designed to provide students with the conceptual tools and methodologies to understand a classic work of literature; while C) will provide students with an opportunity to make connections between their own individual concerns and those of the great characters of literature. At the end of the course, students will have encountered some of the most esteemed classics in literary history. No previous studies in literature needed to take this course. Students interested in discussing the ideas, ideals and values of classic literary texts are welcome to attend this course.

NB: students are expected to read only EXCERPTS of the works. However, it is expected that students will read at least ONE full-length work (for the course essay).

By the end of the course, students should be able to:

* Identify salient features of literary texts from a broad range of classics (Analysis and Evaluation)
* Demonstrate knowledge of the historical developments of literature (Knowledge and Synthesis)
* Support interpretive claims about the importance, relevance and value of masterpieces of literature — in their own context and in society today (Comprehension and Application)
* Produce a well-reasoned essay (Creation and Application)

courses.title: Superheroes in Comics and Film
courses.description:
(UGED2187 is double-coded with ENGE2140.)

What’s a hero? What’s a superhero? Why and when do we need superheroes? How to be one and who gets to be one? We will begin by tracing the origins of this enduring pop fiction, from the hero’s journey in antiquity to the outbreak of the Second World War. We will also explore the moral ambiguity and mixed values of some of the most memorable characters. Furthermore, we will examine revisionist approaches to the superhero genre that respond to the hopes and disillusionments of the contemporary era. Topics covered will include good and evil, power and identity, and justice and responsibility. You may also have the chance to design your own superheroes. It is hoped that by the end of the course, you will develop new ways of reading superhero narratives as uniquely modern myths.

courses.description:
(UGED2194 is double-coded with ENGE2360.)

This course will provide an outline of developments in children’s literature in England and parts of Europe through the study of some essential, central texts as well as recent books for children. The uses of fantasy and the educational aspects of books for children will be discussed, along with notions of childhood and the nature of children. Through close reading of set texts students will be able to engage in critical techniques applicable to most literature, for the best texts for children satisfy sensitive adult readers too.

Introduction: “Childhood is the Kingdom where Nobody Dies” - We will look at childhood as an inner affective condition rather than a biological condition.

Romantic Notions of Childhood: Songs of Innocence and Experience – We will analyse how the poems convey social critique.

Narrating the Real World: The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-time – We analyse the genre of realism in children’s literature.

courses.description:
(UGED2195 is double-coded with ENGE2110.)

This course takes a closer look at the genre of crime fiction. The course outlines a broad perspective of the genre of crime fiction from its earliest incarnations to modern-day TV drama. We will explore a variety of different forms of crime fiction, and how the genre more generally reflects cultural, historical and social issues. The study material for this course will consist of literary texts, TV series, and films drawn from the popular cultural canon. Topics we will discuss include conspiracy, serial crime, trauma, the epistemology of clues, history and crime, and the criminal mind. The course begins with a historical overview of detective fiction, and concludes with a creative workshop on how to write a detective story. Students with a taste for murder, crime, and suspense — and above all the desire to solve enigmas and mysteries — are welcome to attend this course.

courses.subject: UGED
courses.title: Gods Behaving Badly: Myths and Legends from Around the World
courses.description:
(UGED2197 is double-coded with ENGE2190.)

The course will consider myths and legends from around the world with particular sensitivity to one peculiar aspect of them: that the gods depicted in them often behave no better than the people whose lives they determine. In order to explain why this is the case, the course will seek to understand the nature and function of myth, and the complex uses to which they are put in order to explain some of our most pressing questions: How did we all begin? Where are we? Who are we? Why is there so much wrong with the world? What’s the solution? Where will we go when we die? How will it all end? Although the concept of myth might seem outdated in modern secular culture, by drawing comparisons between the ancient and contemporary worlds, students will be encouraged to see how myth-making of some kind is as inevitable and innately human as the questions which prompt it. The course will begin by establishing some archetypal similarities between myths – from myths of Creation to myths of Apocalypse – and then consider myths from specific cultures – including Greco-Roman, Scandinavian, and Chinese – before considering the appeal of myth in contemporary popular culture, especially The Lord of Rings, and Game of Thrones.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
UGED2197 is double-coded with ENGE2190. 
Not for English; English Studies and English Language Education (ELED) Majors; and students who have taken ENGE2190. 
Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
courses.learning_outcomes:
* Students will acquire knowledge of the different types of myths from ancient and contemporary worlds in order to comprehend the similarities and differences between them.

* Students will learn to analyse various myths as vehicles for cultural values and anxieties.

* Students will evaluate the power and persuasiveness of myths to give answers to presiding moral and existential questions including the meaning of life, the nature of death, and the existence of God.

* Students will synthesise their knowledge of a broad range of myths in order to understand the greater role of myth in human society.

* Students will critique the way contemporary technology has facilitated a new conception of mythology and myth-making.

* Students will evaluate the representation of gender in myth.

courses.subject: UGED
courses.title: Song and Poetry: The Literature of Song and Song-Writing
courses.description:
(UGED2199 is double-coded with ENGE2210.)
This course takes a closer look at the intimate connections between song and poetry. The history of song has always been closely connected with the oral tradition in literature; conversely, the musicality of literature owes much to the song tradition. Gospel, Negro Spirituals, Folk Music, the Bard Tradition, the Sean Nós tradition, the ballad and the lyric form in poetry, as well as popular music and musicals will all be examined in this course. The course will examine the different song traditions in their social and political contexts. The course will also include a song-writing element. There will be a song-writing workshop with a well-known local songwriter. Students will be asked to write a song in any genre of their choice (folk song, protest song, spiritual song etc.) and then to have that song performed either by themselves or someone else in the class. No previous studies in literature or music are needed to take this course. Students interested in exploring the connections between song and poetry and between song-writing and the poetic craft are welcome to attend this course.

courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students should be able to:

* understand the historical developments of different song traditions
* understand better how song and poetry are connected
* appreciate the importance, relevance and value of songwriting in the history of literature
* produce a well-reasoned essay

courses.subject: UGED
courses.title: Understanding Chinese Art through Exhibitions
courses.description:
(UGED2286 is double-coded with CURE2406.)

The exhibition has become a site of knowledge production and a prominent and diverse part of contemporary culture. Regarding “Chinese art” as a social constructed concept, the course uses “exhibition” as an entry point to engage with issues concerning Chinese art and to explore the role played by exhibitions in the formation of the knowledge of Chinese art. It introduces the current theories and debates on the theory and history of exhibition, and the display methods, examining the changing concept of Chinese art and curatorial practices through detailed analysis of case studies. The first part of the course traces the formation of the concept of “Chinese art” by looking closely at the history of exhibitions on Chinese objects from the late Qing dynasty to the early twentieth century. The second part examines important exhibitions that have shaped our understanding of Chinese art. Structured thematically, the course discusses the curatorial concepts of selective significant international exhibitions on Chinese art, and investigate how scholarly research has been transformed into exhibitions which have shaped our understanding of Chinese art, constructed identity and been deployed for political ends.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
UGED2286 is double-coded with CURE2406. 
Not for Cultural Management (CUMS and CUMT) Majors; Public Humanities and students who have taken CUMT2006 or CURE2406.
Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon the completion of the course, students will be able to:

·Explain the theories of exhibition and the changing concepts of Chinese art

·Identify and describe the important exhibitions on Chinese art and prominent Chinese art objects.

·Identify and evaluate the curatorial ideas of important exhibitions on Chinese art.

·Select research materials and Chinese art objects to develop original research.

·Design and plan a virtual exhibition based on original research.

courses.subject: UGED
courses.title: Understanding in Practice: From Meditation to Mindfulness
courses.description:
Each day, our life is flooded with thoughts and emotions aroused by noises outside and inside of us. Do these thoughts and emotions support the real purpose of our life, bringing fulfillment and happiness? Or do they make our life an endless cycle of stress, anger, fear, and even hopelessness? The course offers an orientation into mindfulness meditation as a possible way of “resetting,” at personal and inter-personal levels. Emphasis is on reflective participation, supplemented by knowledge of basic concepts and principles.

From the formal practice of sitting cross-legged and quietly counting the breaths to the informal practice of embracing each moment in daily life, students will be guided to cultivate samma sati, or “right mindfulness,” one of the Eightfold Paths to end suffering. Mindfulness meditation (MM) is grounded in ancient Buddhist sutras named Anapanasati (“mindfulness breathing”) and Satipatthana (“foundation of mindfulness”) and 2,500 years of lay and monastic practice. It aims for the practitioner to develop one-pointed concentration on the body, feelings, mind, and dharmas (phenomena), and thereby to reflect on their impermanence, comprehend no-self, and cultivate loving kindness. Over the past decades, a whole range of secular mindfulness practices, or mindfulness-based interventions (MBIs), have emerged to serve therapeutic and educational purposes. Students may also explore one or more of such modern applications, and ponder the contribution of mindfulness training to good health and well-being (Sustainable Development Goal 3), and to Education for Sustainable Development (ESD) as a whole.

The course will take students on a one-week retreat in a Buddhist meditation centre, preceded by readings and presentations on relevant topics, and followed by a personal reflection and a mini-research on the experience. Through undisturbed practice of mindfulness meditation away from home and along with peers and monastics, students will master the basic skills of the formal practice and begin to develop a habit of mindful living. Hopefully, they will cultivate a sense of self-compassion and connectedness with fellow human beings that fosters emotion management, harmonious relation and wise social action.
