courses.course_syllabus:
The **major concepts and practices** to be covered include, but are not limited to, the following aspects of mindfulness meditation:

* *(1) Basic Concepts and Principles**

* Non-duality in the *Heart Sutra*/*Heart of Understanding*
* The Buddha’s story: *dukkha* (suffering), *metta* (loving kindness), *samadhi* (meditation)
* Four Noble Truths: from *dukkha* to impermanence, no-self, dependent origination
* Eightfold Path: *sila* (morality), *samadhi* (meditation), *prajna* (insight)
* The Four Immeasurables: from *metta* to *karuna*, *mudita*, and *upekkha*
* Right *Samadhi* 正定: stages of *dhyana* (meditation 禪定), *ekaggata* (one-pointedness/心一境性), *vipassana* (insight-meditation 內觀)
* Right Mindfulness 正念: *Sati* (bare awareness): (impermanence of) five aggregates, four foundations of mindfulness, seven factors of awakening, five remembrances

* *(2) Mindfulness Meditation**

* Body as temple: awareness of body (breaths, bodily sensations, sound), feelings, and thoughts; non-judgmental observation; letting go; habit energy
* Sitting Meditation: posture, focus on breaths and sound
* Others methods of meditation (e.g., walking, eating, tea sharing, flower arrangement, drum, forest bathing, etc.)
* Five Mindfulness Trainings

* *(3) Study of the Mind**

* Mind-only School: the eight levels of consciousness
* The neuroscientist’s perspective

* *(4) Developments in Modern Times**

* *Personal*: Dealing with anger, fear, etc.; Mindfulness-based Stress Reduction
* *Inter-personal*: Nonviolent Communication
* *Socio-political*: Engaged Buddhism
* *Nature:* Forest Bathing

* *(5) Mindfulness and Sustainability**

* Mindfulness for Health and Well-being (Sustainable Development Goal 3)
* Mindfulness as Education for Sustainable Development (ESD)

The course will be **implemented** in three steps:

1. Before the retreat, students must fulfill the following requirements to qualify for participation (and sponsorship, if any) for the retreat:

- Attendance at two lectures for a general introduction to Buddhist mindfulness and meditation practice (with references to the *Satipatthana Sutra* and the *Anapanasati Sutra*); with a quiz given at the end of the second lecture, and one or more workshops on different forms of meditation

- Report on a book/article on one of the following topics: (1) Engaged Buddhism, (2) Mindfulness Meditations, (3) Nonviolent Communication, (4) Emotion Management (dealing with anger, fear, etc.), (5) Mindfulness-based Interventions (e.g., MBRS, MBCT, etc.), and (6) Mindfulness and Neuroscience. A list of recommended books and articles will be offered for students’ choice; students may also propose their own titles and seek the instructor’s approval; and

- Participation in a seminar to share presentations on the book/article report (subject to arrangement at the retreat centre chosen, the presentation may take place during the retreat).
2. During the retreat, students will practice periods of silence, sitting meditation and other forms of guided meditation, and learn to be mindful throughout the day, in eating, walking, working, exercising, etc. They will be required to attend talks and ceremonies, and share their reflections and raise questions in gatherings during the retreat. Students must participate in all activities of the retreat with satisfactory performance to qualify for any sponsorship available for the trip.
3. After the retreat, students will write a final report to reflect on the experience and to conduct a mini-research on a topic of interest emerging from the retreat, the result of which they will present at a final student seminar.

courses.subject: UGED
courses.title: Religious Art of China
courses.description:
(UGED2306 is double-coded with FAAS2110.)

This course aims at exploring the relationship between Chinese art and religion from the Shang period onwards. Students will be introduced to religious paintings, buildings, sculptures, clothes and ritual objects. Through studying important archaeological and extant religious artifacts and recent research on Chinese religious beliefs, students are expected to understand the characteristics and significance of Chinese religious arts. Religious ideas behind different forms of art will also be discussed.

courses.course_syllabus:
1. 圖像、目的、意義：早期青銅禮器

‧禮器上的紋飾與當時的宗教祭祀有何關係？

‧怎樣詮釋商周青銅器上的動物紋飾的宗教目的和意義才算合理？

2. 器物群組與思想：先秦至漢墓葬形制及隨葬品

‧分析一件宗教藝術品與詮釋一組墓葬出土文物的宗教性有何差異？

‧如何通過對比先秦至漢墓葬形制及隨葬品組合，得知時人對死後世界的看法？

3. 物料、目的、意義：早期墓葬中的玉和石

‧物料如何取得其在特定文化中的宗教含義？

‧先秦至漢代的人如何使用玉石建構他們理想的死後世界？

4. 圖像群組與功能：從西王母到仙佛祥瑞圖像

‧**何謂祥瑞？祥瑞圖在中國傳統社會有何功能？**

‧**設置在漢至六朝的宗教建築和器物上的仙佛圖像，如何令其使用者達至吉祥的目的？**

5. 神靈與地理：山嶽崇拜與早期山水圖像

‧山在中國古代的宇宙觀中有何重要性？

‧先秦以來對山嶽的崇拜如何衍生出各種以山水為題材的藝術作品？

6. 佛教壁畫、文本與地方文化：敦煌和新彊壁畫中的佛傳故事、本生故事、因緣故事

‧何謂佛傳故事、本生故事、因緣故事？

‧這些宗教主題在敦煌和新彊兩地不同的文化影響下，如何在壁畫上呈現各自的藝術特色和信仰重點？

7. 佛教壁畫、文本與儀式：經變畫

‧何謂經變畫？

‧敦煌的經變畫如何體現地方信徒對經文的理解、地方工藝傳統，以及經變畫的功能？

8. 佛教造像、文本與地方文化：佛教造像與觀音變相

‧佛教的經典如何解釋典型佛教造像的特徵？

‧以觀音菩薩為例，其在印度佛教和佛經中的形像，如何結合中國地方文化而改變？

9. 佛教思想與民間想像：六道輪迴、地獄的繪畫與石刻

‧佛經中如何描述六道與地獄？

‧ 中國民間對死後世界的思像，如何影響佛教有關六道輪迴和地獄圖像在中國的發展？

10. 宇宙圖式：道教的道、仙道、丹道的圖像表現

‧宇宙（Cosmos）在道教的思想中有何重要性？

‧宋代以來，道教如何運用圖像來表達其仙道和丹道的思想？

11. 道教神仙與地方信仰：永樂宮與呂祖信仰

‧道教如何建構其神仙系譜並將之以圖像呈現？甚麼因素促使神仙的形像改變？

‧ 從元代山西永樂宮到現今香港的道堂，呂祖（呂洞賓）的形像經歷了微妙的變化。

12. 神靈與地理：武當山與真武大帝

‧ 神靈如何與特定地點建立關係？皇室與信眾在當中扮演怎樣的角色？

13. 宇宙圖式：密教與藏傳佛教的曼荼羅

‧密教與藏傳佛教如何透過平面和立體的曼荼羅表達對宇宙的理解？

‧佛教、道教的宇宙圖式在概念和功能上有何差異？

courses.subject: UGED
courses.title: Introduction to Asian Art: The Art and Archaeology of West, South, Southeast, and Inner Asia
courses.description:
(UGED2315 is double-coded with FAAS2113.)

The survey introduces the art and material culture of pre-20th century Asia with particular attention paid to trans-regional and cross-cultural interactions. Select artistic traditions in West (mainly, Iran), South (India, Sri Lanka, and the Himalayas), Southeast (Indonesia, Burma, Thai, Cambodia, Laos, and Vietnam), and Inner (Afghanistan, Tajikistan, Kazakhstan, Uzbekistan, Kyrgyzstan, Turkmenistan, and Mongolia) will be examined against their philosophical, religious, socio-political, economic, aesthetic, and technological backgrounds. Major themes include (1) the rise of civilizations, (2) developments of various artistic forms and media, (3) tombs and funerary paraphernalia, (4) the spread of Buddhism, Hinduism, Islamism, and other worldviews across the region, and (5) Indianization and Sinicization.

courses.subject: UGED
courses.title: Life and Arts in Pre-Modern China
courses.description:
(UGED2316 is double-coded with FAAS2100.)

In the traditional discourse of Chinese painting, it was believed that an artist should “外師造化，中得心源” (outwardly learn from the Nature and inwardly trace the source of their own heart). Unfortunately, with the enormous temporal and geographical difference, both the Nature and the “heart-source” of the ancient masters, as well as their techniques in articulating the two, appear to be unapproachable to us living in the modern age. Likewise, the field’s ambiguous meta-language full of expressions like “氣韻生動” (infusing ch’i to show life movement) or “意趣” (subtle charm resulted from spontaneity) can also be a hurdle to uninitiated students.

Distant it might seem, art, after all, is inspired by real life. This course seeks to explore the material basis of the Nature artistically heightened by the ancient artists directed by their “heart-source”. We would try to explore the abstract philosophical ideas and aesthetic ideals by looking at something physical and concrete: by visiting specific scenic sites, we would be able to compare the landscape with the paintings they inspired and have more idea on how the visual vocabulary and grammar of Chinese painting “translates” the real world; and by viewing the objects, or even experience some of the activities central to the artists’ cultural life, students would also have a more substantial understanding on the “heart-source” of these painters.

This course would use the Songjiang and Wu Schools of painting as case studies. A field trip will be organized and students will be walked through the areas of Shanghai, Suzhou and Hangzhou where the Ming Dynasty painters were active in. Through the well-preserved tangible heritage of the region, students could have a better feeling of the intangible ideational world of the ancient masters and their artistic pursuits. The endeavours of the local communities in preserving these invaluable treasures will also be reviewed.

courses.learning_outcomes:
1. 能有意識地以連結自身生活經驗的方式觀看藝術，發掘藝術與自身的關聯

2. 比較真實的山川地貌與其在不同畫家筆下迥異的呈現方式，從而觀照中國繪畫程式化語言的發展

3. 分析明代藝術文化之盛與江南物質生活之豐的關係

4. 思考古人的生活與藝術在現代社會的意義並了解現時有哪些保護文化遺產的努力

After completing the course, students should be able to:

1. Appreciate artworks in relation to their personal experience and discover the relevance of art to them.

2. Relate topographical features to the styles of individual artists, which would later become pictorial conventions

3. Attribute the flourishing of art and culture of the Ming period to the prosperity of the Jiangnan region.

4. Evaluate the meaning of ancient life and art to modern people and understand what have been done to keep the cultural heritage alive.
courses.course_syllabus:
* *甲、山水之間「師造化」** **——** **旅遊、觀察自然與藝術創作**

- 「不行萬里路，不讀萬卷書，欲作畫祖，其可得乎？」：古今山水畫的歷史及美學

- 自然的真實與藝術的真實：啓發藝術的山水風光及傳統技法下的山水風光

* *乙、「心源」之源** **——** **明代文人的生活與其思想及藝術**

- 中晚明社會：繁榮市場經濟及對隱逸淡泊的追求並存

- 明代文人文房之雅 （對書畫、篆刻、碑帖、瓷器、紫砂、玉雕等收藏的審美）

- 明代文人生活之雅 （昆曲、園林、絲綢、遊山玩水）

* *丙、古代藝術的當代呈現與存在意義**

- 歷史與文化傳統的當代價值

- 文化傳承的多種手法 （博物館、文化旅遊、手藝傳承及當代藝術創作）

* *A.** **Travel, Nature and Art**

* *-** The history and aesthetics of Chinese landscape painting

- The “translation” of Nature with the language of ink and brush

* *B.** **Life, Ideas and Art of the Ming Literati**

- Mid to late Ming dynasty: prosperous market economy and the pursuit of hermitage

- Elegance in the studio: Ming dynasty connoisseurship on calligraphy, painting, seal carving, rubbings, porcelain, zisha wares, jade carvings

- Elegance in everyday life: kunqu, garden architecture, silk, travelling

* *C. Representation of ancient art in the modern age and its meaning**

- Relevance of history and culture to the present

- The multiple means to preserve cultural heritage (museum, cultural tourism, apprenticeship, modern art)

courses.title: Human Happiness
courses.description: This course is a philosophical discussion of the idea of happiness. The first part covers major theories of happiness from Western and Chinese tradition. The second part deals with the theoretical issues of happiness: the definition of happiness; distinction between pleasure, happiness, and unhappiness; attainability of happiness; hedonism and eudaemonism; and the meaning of happiness in the contemporary world.

4. Reflect upon and analyze ethical, psychological, and anthropological questions concerning human happiness;

5. Elaborate on the complexity and subjectivity of the issues of human happiness.

6. Cultivate intellectual interests in thinking about the relationship between happiness and human value.

courses.subject: UGED
courses.title: Understanding Comic Arts
courses.description:
(UGED2326 is double-coded with CURE2051.)

Nowadays comic strip has become one of the major forms of visual narratives in our culture. Both comics and film are visual arts originally developed within the period of late 19th century and early 20th century. Although film has long ago established its artistic legitimacy, comic art still struggle for recognition. However, as Will Eisner put it, comic strip is a “Sequential Art” and has its own unique aesthetic nature. This course tries to inquire the governing aesthetic principles of comics and investigate its unique method of expression. We will also try to delineate the special communication mode of comics and its relationship with different aspects of modern society and culture. Students will learn to appreciate comic art from different perspectives, and strengthen analytical skills for visual media.

courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Through the lectures, students will recognize the aesthetic nature of sequential art and locate the humanistic values and meanings of comic arts for modern society and culture.

2. Through tutorial discussions, student will apply the analytical skills and formal methods to interpret comic and visual texts.

3. Through mid-term assignment (research portfolio on the visual representation of comics), student will distinguish, compare, analyze and criticize different visual and multimedia sources.

4. Through final paper, student will prepare and manage to do an academic research on visual representation.

5. Student will aware, judge and appraise the practical values of the analytical skills and historical knowledge provided by this course after they complete the mid-term assignment and final paper.

courses.title: "The Book of Changes" and Wisdom of Life
courses.description: "The Book of Changes" (Yijing) is a highly venerated and influential classic that has made far-reaching impacts on the Chinese religion, philosophy, politics and medicine. It has a far greater significance for the Chinese culture as a book of wisdom than a divination manual, by offering a wealth of knowledge and insights about the cosmos, nature, and life. It shows us the ways to cultivate virtue, enhance ability and perceive wisdom by living our lives and making judgments in harmony with the changing forces of the universe. The store of ancient wisdom accumulated in this classic is often still relevant to our contemporary world that is in constant and rapid technological, social and political changes. Through guided reading of the key notions and themes encapsulated in some selected hexagrams, students may draw from the wellspring of profound wisdom in the "The Book of Changes" to stimulate their reflection on the approach of life, the way of looking at the world, and the recurring issues facing humanity.

courses.subject: UGED
courses.title: Buddhism and Human Life
courses.description:
The spread of Buddhism in China has a long history. The incorporation of Buddhism into Chinese culture marked a great success in intercultural dialogue, as the Chinese adopted and modified teachings and wisdom transmitted into Chinese philosophical wisdom. Buddhism adopts a negative approach of understanding human existence, but its final aim is to transcend nihilism. Topics include:
(1) Development of Primitive Buddhism; (2) Fundamental terminologies of Buddhism; (3) The Buddhist world-view; (4) Buddhist practical methods of wisdom and happiness; (5) Buddhism amid science and technology; and
(6) Zen and practical wisdom of life.

courses.learning_outcomes:

2. Discuss the historical and cultural backgrounds of Buddhism.

3. Illustrate how traditional Buddhist thought can be applied to address the cultural and ethical issues in contemporary world.

4. Read and interpret selected classical texts, and analyze the content and issues addressed.

courses.description: This course aims at providing knowledge about adjustment and personal growth to enable students to develop more effective coping skills and social behaviour. courses.subject: UGED
courses.title: Political Violence and Human Rights
courses.description:
(UGED2622 is double-coded with ANTH2530.)

This course examines the pervasiveness of violence from an anthropological and comparative perspective. We consider a wide range of phenomena that can be called violence within diverse historical and cultural contexts. Violence is always political – whether it is manifest in the spectacular practices of torture, terrorism, or genocide, or the invisible structures of inequalities that generate educational, health, and food inequities. Specifically, we will address four SDG goals in depth: SDG#1 No Poverty, SDG #5 “Gender Equality”, SDG# 8 Decent Work and Economic Growth, SDG #10 “Reduced Inequalities” and SDG #16 “Peace, Justice and strong institutions”; The topics covered will be understood in relation to histories of colonialism and nationalism, ideologies about race, gender, and variant forms of social, economic, and political hierarchies. We further examine the effectiveness and limitations of human rights and humanitarianism as remedies, including the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs).

Topic 1. Can violence be apolitical? Can human rights be wrong?

Topic 2. The politics of representation – Violence and Rights

Topic 3. Violence as a spectrum and knowledge production
Topic 4 Human rights as cultural practice

* *Part II considers through empirical studies the agents and structures of violence (SGD 1, 8, 10, 16)**

* *Part IV considers global migration and humanitarianism (SDG 1, 8, 16)**

courses.subject: UGED
courses.title: Understanding Movies
courses.description:
(UGED2637 is double-coded with COMM2930.)

This course aims at helping students to earn a solid vocabulary and a sharp eye in analyzing films. Students will learn about the basic cinematic techniques and structures, including mise-en-scene and montage, use of cinematic time and space, the image, soundtrack, and the script. Theoretical perspectives such as realism, feminism, postmodernism would be introduced to address the political, economic and socio-cultural implications of movies. Equipped with these analytical tools, students can critically appreciate movies of different era and different places.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
UGED2637 is double-coded with COMM2930. 
Not for GCOM; COMM Majors; and students who have taken COMM2930. 
Co-requisite: UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or UGFN1001 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Students will be able to develop cine-literacy and analyze movies through the comprehension of film languages.

2. Students will be able to relay the movies to their broader contexts of production and consumption and through which to understand the culturaldiversity.

3. Students will be able to critically reflect upon ideologies underlying the film texts.

4. Students will be able to discuss existing and emergent challenges facing by human world through the discussion of the relationship of movies and current thoughts such as feminism and post-modernism.

5. Students will be able to produce a critical film analysis that reflects upon political, social and cultural issues embedded in film texts.
courses.course_syllabus:
The course consists of three main parts: (I) film form and aesthetics (week 1 to 4); (II) two main categories of movies (week 5 and 6); (III) critical theories (week 7 to 12). The first part equips students with specific film languages for film appreciation. The discussion of avant-garde movies and genre draws students’ attention to the dynamics as well as the competition between the two major modes of cultural productions. The last part introduces a variety of critical theories that will lead the understanding of movies to the rethinking of significant issues of human concerns. Key concepts will be introduced so that students can apply them in formulating their film analysis. The sequence of these issues implies a progression of knowledge from film specific to interdisciplinary approach and from film appreciation to critical evaluation.

The following is an outline of the course:

(1) Introduction: Film Styles: Realism and Formalism

This lecture will introduce the two major styles of films: realism and formalism. It aims to explain how film is being perceived as an art form and as a representation of reality. The introduction leads students to think of the nature of movie.

Key concept: film style, formalism and realism

Movies: *The Rules of the Game* (1939), *Last Year at Marienbad* (France/Italy 1961),《香港製造》(1997), 《天水圍的日與夜》(2008), 《東邪西毒》(1994),

(2) Film Narrative

This lecture will talk about how story is being narrated in movies through the elaboration of film structure. The concept of motif is highlighted to direct students to pay attention to how visual elements are contributed to the story telling in movies.

Key words: narrative Structure, story and plot, motifs,

Movies: *Rashomon* (1950), *Confessions* (告白，2011)

(3) Film Style: mise-en-scene

This lecture will present a major concept used in film appreciation—mise-en- scene. It explains how various visual elements including set design, costume, make-up, framing, cinematography, lighting etc. are articulating the meaning of the movies.

Key word: mise-en-scene

Movies: *The Conformist* (1970), *Clockwork Orange* (1971), *Old Boy* (2003), *the Artist* (2002)

(4) Film Style: Editing and Sound

This lecture will elucidate how post-production techniques such as editing, sound mixing and music can create meaning. The concepts will be related to the two major film styles of realism and formalism.

Key words: montage, continuity

Movies:*t**he Battleship Potemkin* (1925), *Psycho* (1960), *Godfather* (1972), *Apocalypse Now* (1979), *Run Rola Run* (1998)

(5) Auteur Theory and Avant-garde Movies

After introducing basic film languages in the previous lessons, this lecture will introduce auteur theory and avant-garde movies to exemplify movie as art. Auteur theory stresses the importance of understanding movies as imprints of film directors’ aesthetic policy and creative deployment of film languages. The discussion will lead to examination of the nature of avant-garde movie that embraces experimental spirit.

Keywords: auteur theory, avant-garde

Movies: *Meshes of the Afternoon* (1943), *Breathless* (1960), *Kika* (1993), *Volver* (2007)

(6) Film genres and blockbusters

This lecture introduces the opposite of avant-garde movies – genre movies. It also relates conventional making with Hollywood movies production

Keywords: genres, spectatorship.

Movies: *Chicago (2003)*, *Perhaps Love* (2005), *Sin City* (2005)

(7) Movies: Film and Ideologies: Class and Ethnic

This lecture aims to go beyond film languages by relate films to broader social contexts. The concept of ideology will be introduced to allow students to critically examine the power relations underpinning film texts. Class and racial stereotypes in movies will be used to demonstrate the ideological contestation and identity politics in movies.

Key Words: Ideology, stereotype

Movies: *Color Purple* (1985), *Titanic* (1997),

(8) Movies: Gender and Sexuality

This lecture continues the discussion of identity politics by analyzing how gender and sexuality are being represented and constructed in movies. Feminism and queer theory will be introduced not only to address the subject matters but also explain the transformation of film critiques from ideological approach to broader cultural studies of institutions and audiences.

Key concepts: feminism, gender, sexuality, queer theory, camp

Movies: 《金枝玉葉》(1994), *Boys Don’t Cry* (1999)

(9) Movies and the Nation

This lecture will introduce how the idea of national cinema is expressed and transformed. It problematizes the nation-state, sensitizing students’ awareness of the nation as constructed imagined communities of which the cinema takes a central place.

Keywords: nation-state, imagined communities

Movies: *The Birth of a Nation (*1915),《賽德克·巴萊》(2011)

(10) Movies and Globalization:

While the previous lecture delineates the significance of movies in building national identity, this lecture will discuss the consequence of the growing trend of globalization of movies production. Issues such as cultural homogenization and heterogenization, the clash of civilizations and local appropriation would be addressed.

Keywords: globalization, cultural homogenization and heterogenization, crash of civilization

Movies: *Infernal Affairs* (2003), *the Departed* (2006), *Avatar* (2005), the *Innocence of Muslims* (2012)

(11) Movies and Post-modernism

This lecture will address how movies are responded, aesthetically and thematically, to issues brought about by the distrust of modernism and the over-development of modernity. The discussion will address particularly the crisis of self-identity.

Key words: post-modernism, deconstruction, self-identity

Movies: *Metropolis* (1927), *the Matrix* (1999), *Suzhou River* (2000)

(12) Synthesis: Citizen Kane

This lecture uses the classical movie “Citizen Kane” to illustrate the complex nature of movie and the synthesis of multiple language systems in film texts.

Movies: *Citizen Kane* (1941)

(13) Group Presentation

courses.subject: UGED
courses.title: Human Existence and Values Education
courses.description: This course aims to inquire into the essence of human existence and its close connection with values consciousness, in order to see that values education is necessary to be "truly human". The contents of the course include reflection on the conditions of human existence in the process of industrialization and globalization and investigation of various conceptions of human existence, such as in Materialism, Evolutionism, Freud, Christianity, Existentialism, Kant and Confucianism. The course concludes that the essence of human existence resides in human subjectivity and values consciousness. Based on such contentions, it will examine the meaning and types of values, and pinpoint the importance of values education to elevate the consciousness of students. Finally it inquires into the meaning of values education and the essence of Aesthetic Education, Religious Education and especially Moral Education in order to recognise their importance in making people "truly human".
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students majoring in programmes offered by Faculty of Education; not for CLED and ELED Majors. Co-requisite: UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or UGFN1001 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. To enable students to investigate into the nature of human existence and understand the essence of truly human resides in man's subjectivity and values consciousness.

2. To enable students to reflect and be aware the condition of human existence in the process of industrialization and globalization.

3. To enable students to be aware that values education is greatly importance for every human being.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Crisis of Industrialization and Globalization:-

- decline of religion and lost of values, dehumanization, alienation, bureaucratization, sensationalism

- third phrase of capitalism, economic injustice, Americanization

2. Different theories and conceptions of human nature and human existence: Materialism, Evolutionism, Freud, Christianity, Existentialism, Kant, Confucianism.

3. Meaning and types of values: truth, beauty, good, holy, utility.

4. Meaning and scope of Values Education: brief history, moral education, aesthetic education, religious education.

5. Values education and human existence: Values consciousness, approaches to values and moral education, Confucian values education, cultivation of aesthetic and spiritual values.

courses.subject: UGED
courses.title: Ethics and the Human Experience
courses.description:
(UGED2666 is double-coded with ANTH2360.)

This course introduces students to the study of morality and ethics from a social and cross-cultural perspective. Morality and ethics became a distinct area for anthropological inquiry as recently as the beginning of the 21st century. Why this topic is relatively new in anthropology has something to do with the way in which moral differences have been conflated with cultural differences in the history of the discipline. In other words, anthropologists have long presumed that differences between right and wrong, good and bad, are culturally constructed. In recent years, however, this conflation has been questioned and problematized, with reference to the problem of competing moral goods within a single society and the role of the individual in negotiating moral commitments. Having much to say about cultural differences as well as contingent social processes, anthropologists are now in an even better position to contribute to cross-disciplinary conversations about the nature of morality and ethics. By exploring morality and ethics from a social and cross-cultural perspective, this course will demonstrate that morality and ethics is by no means an abstract subject best studied by philosophers. Students will be encouraged to see ethics as a part of their everyday lives, and to see the lives of others as shaped by shared human problems such as how to get along with other people, and how to get along with oneself.

This course is divided into four major units. It begins with an issue highly relevant to university students: the responsibility individuals carry for their own success and self-fulfillment in capitalist societies. The second unit considers why moral and cultural differences have been conflated, and how different societies have responded to shared human problems in different ways. The third unit explores the relationship between morality and the creation and maintenance of social relationships. Case studies of small communities in different parts of the world will be especially helpful for understanding morality and ethics from a social perspective, as cooperation can be fragile yet so important in small communities. Topics and readings in the last unit offer resources for enriching and expanding our vocabulary of virtues. Students will be invited to conduct research into the mundane things ordinary people do to take care of one another in daily life.

courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Students will acquire intellectual resources for thinking about ethics and morality from a holistic perspective.

2. Students will learn to differentiate between the various factors that create unique social, cultural and historical circumstances.

3. Students will learn to connect the seemingly mundane to broader philosophical themes.

4. Students will have a better understanding of their own life experience.

5. Students will apply the skills they have learned in doing a class presentation on a topic of their choosing, in collaboration with group-mates.

courses.subject: UGED
courses.title: Preserving Cultural Heritage
courses.description:
(UGED2668 is double-coded with ANTH2730.)

This course aims to give students the basic knowledge and training on cultural heritage preservation, including archaeological excavation, report and analysis, and the preservation of ancient architectures and monuments. The course includes the following topics:
(1) concepts and international conventions/policies of cultural heritage preservation; (2) archaeological recording and analysis; and
(3) preservation of ancient architectures and monuments: intangible and digital heritage standards and procedures.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
UGED2668 is double-coded with ANTH2730. 
Not for Anthropology Majors; and students who have taken ANTH2730. 
Co-requisite: UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or UGFN1001 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
courses.learning_outcomes:
After taking this course, students are expected to:

1) understand the basic concepts, principles and approaches of managing cultural heritage.

2) learn to appreciate cultural heritage created by human beings, and to respect different cultures.

3) understand the economic, social and political issues of heritage preservation and management in contemporary societies.

4) cultivate the ability of inter-disciplinary thinking and critical thinking.

5) broaden the academic horizons and knowledge.
courses.course_syllabus:
Shall we preserve the old things, and why? What is “cultural heritage”? Using examples in different parts of the world, this course aims to give students a concise and critical understanding on heritage conservation from an anthropological perspective. The course will introduce basic concepts and cultural contexts of the occurrence and development of cultural heritage conservation in the world, and discuss important issues in this field, including the economic, social and political meanings of heritage in contemporary societies, the impetus of preserving heritage, and the use of heritage as a social and political implement by the state, scholars, and different communities for their own interests. The course will also discuss problems and challenges in this area.

No prior knowledge on heritage preservation is required for this course.

Major contents of this course are as follows:

Why are human beings interested in their past? Is heritage “invented”?

The origin and development of heritage conservation will be explored and discussed.

Debates on heritage preservation and management:

1. Who needs cultural heritage? Is heritage conservation a social elite business?

2. Who owns the cultural heritage, and who has the right to decide what should be reserved, and how to preserve it?

3. International principles and local cultures, globalization and localization: the preservation of cultural heritage in different political, economic and social contexts/ countries—should there be “universal principles and philosophy” for heritage conservation? Is there a so-called “best practice”? Who has the right to decide what is “the best practice”?

courses.subject: UGED
courses.title: Death, Death Ritual and Culture
courses.description:
(UGED2669 is double-coded with ANTH2351.)

Death is both a human universal and a process deeply affected by the cultural context in which it occurs. Dealing with death, both practically and psychologically, is something that all humans must face. This course examines death and death ritual through the question of what is universal and what is culturally variant about how humans face death. It looks at death and death ritual in both modern and pre-modern contexts and analyses it socially, psychologically, politically, and culturally. From the course students will learn how the treatment of death varies cross-culturally; how understandings of death have shifted over human cultural evolution; what aspects of death are universal in human experience; and how death affects contemporary politics, economics, and culture.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
UGED2669 is double-coded with ANTH2351. 
Not for Anthropology Majors; and students who have taken ANTH2351. 
Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
courses.course_syllabus:
* *Week 1, Sex and Death: Human Universals or Cultural Constructions?**

This week examines what about human understandings and experiences of death are universal and what varies cross-culturally.

* *Week 2, Conceptualizing Death**

This week explores different ways of imagining the process of death and its relationship to life.

* *Week 3, Death Ritual as a Process**

This week considers what death ritual accomplishes in different societies. Particular attention will be paid to differing ways of handling the dead body.

* *Week 4, The Denial of Death; Psychologies of Death and Dying**

This week presents and analyzes theories of the psychological mechanisms that allow humans to deal with the knowledge that death is unavoidable for both them and their loved ones.

* *Week 5, Death in Chinese and Japanese Societies**

This week examines conceptions of death and death ritual in China and Japan, both traditionally and in the contemporary world.

* *Week 6, Grief and Mourning**

This week considers the universality of mourning as well as culturally divergent ways of dealing with the problem of grief.

* *Week 7, Ghosts and Haunting**

This week analyzes the presence of ideas about ghosts and haunting in a wide variety of societies and explore what these ideas tell us about humanity.

* *Week 8, Uncommon Death, Witchcraft, and Vengeance**

This week considers the human propensity to find a cause for death and link it to the punishment of particular individuals in different societies.

* *Week 9, Death, Politics, and Power**

This week analyzes the ways in which the problematic of death interlinks with politics at the level of the nation-state.

* *Week 10, Death and Modernity**

This week examines how understandings of death have shifted with modernity: industrialization, urbanization, and the rise of science.

* *Week 11, Governing Death; Death and the State**

This week explores how governments regulate death in a range of different societies.

* *Week 12, The Economies of Death and Death Ritual**

This week portrays the economic processes linked to funerals and death, including commercial transactions, inheritance, insurance, and gift giving.

* *Week 13, The Future of Death**

This week examines how death might change in the future, including speculations about the biological possibilities of reversing aging, the technologies of transferring consciousness to computers or cyborg bodies, and the beliefs of people interested in promoting these technologies.

courses.title: Contemplative Practices and Holistic Education
courses.description: Holistic education aims at developing human wholeness of students rather than focusing only on achievement and assessment. Contemplative practices, which originated in Asian and Western ancient traditions, have been studied and applied in education, helping professions, and medicine for promoting self-awareness, well-being, mind-body health in the past few decades. This course provides an overview of the philosophical and spiritual roots, cultural influences, and recent scientific studies of contemplative practices in the context of holistic education (SDG#4 Quality education). After introduction of the diverse heritage of contemplative practices in East and West, followed by examining concepts and theories of contemplative practices in disciplines of philosophies, neurosciences, medicine, psychology, and education, students will reflect critically daily life experiences for developing healthy and sustainable lifestyle in the modern world with various contemplative practices (SDG#3 Good health & well-being; SDG#12 Responsible consumption and Production). Ethical attitudes are articulated through building interpersonal connection for cultivating global awareness on topics of peace and justice (SDG#16 Peace, Justice and Strong Institutions). Apart from lectures, interactive tutorial with experiential practice activities, fieldwork, and reflective journal will be included for comprehensive understanding of the topics.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for majors in Fac. of Education, Chi Lang Studies & Chi Lang Education (CLED) and Eng Studies & Eng Lang Education (ELED). Co-requisite: Any course with "UGFH” or “UGFN" as prefix.

courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of this course, students will be able to:

* Understand the concepts and theories of contemplative practices in holistic approach across multi-disciplines in philosophies, neurosciences, medicine, psychology, and education (#4 Quality education)

* Appreciate the diverse heritage of contemplative practices in Asian and Western traditions in holistic education context (#4 Quality education)

* Establish attitudes and skills of various contemplative practices for enhancing self-awareness for promoting well-being, mind-body health, resilience, and positive characters (i.e. gratitude, forgiveness, loving-kindness, hope) (#3 Good Health and well-being)

* Reflect on issues in daily life experiences and articulate their own judgement by developing positive and ethical attitudes on healthy and sustainable lifestyle in the modern world (#12 Responsible consumption and Production)

* Develop social and global awareness on justice, peace, sustainability through introspection of contemplative practices for building connection in family, school community, society and the mother earth (#16 Peace, Justice and Strong Institutions)
courses.course_syllabus:
Part I - Contemplative practices in diverse traditions

Students will explore various contemplative practices from the texts in the Eastern and Western traditions from pre-modern to contemporary era.

1. Introduction: Contemplative education in well-being and holistic approaches

- Brief introduction of holistic education and its relationship with contemplative practices and well-being [SDG-GE#3 Good Health and well-being; #4 Quality education]

1. Eastern traditions: Confucian, Taoist, Buddhist, Yogic, etc.

- Examination of some key concepts and contemplative practices in major Chinese and Indian traditions, including Confucian, Taoist, Buddhist, and Yogic traditions

[SDG-GE#3 Good Health and well-being; #4 Quality education]

1. Western traditions: Rumi, Saint Teresa of Avila, Thomas Merton, Emerson, etc.

- Examination of some key concepts and contemplative practices in major Western traditions, including Sufi and early Catholic contemplative traditions

[SDG-GE#3 Good Health and well-being; #4 Quality education]

Part II – Contemplative pedagogy in the holistic education context

Students will apply various contemplative practices for well-being education and related evidence-based research from disciplines of neuroscience, psychology, and holistic education. The interactive tutorial will provide opportunities for students to experience the practices.

1. Attention, concentration and brain state (i.e. centering, mindful sitting)

- Introduction of evidence-based contemplative practices which can improve attention and concentration; practices of mindful sitting and centering are introduced in classroom setting

[SDG-GE#3 Good Health and well-being; #4 Quality education]

1. Contemplative movement and self-awareness (i.e. mindful walking, labyrinth, Qigong)

- Introduction of evidence-based contemplative practices which can improve self-awareness and self-regulation; contemplative practices of movement are introduced in classroom setting

[SDG-GE#3 Good Health and well-being; #4 Quality education]

1. Loving-kindness, empathy, compassion, and interpersonal connection

- Introduction of evidence-based practices which can improve empathy, compassion, and interpersonal connection; contemplative practices of loving-kindness are introduced in classroom setting

[SDG-GE#3 Good Health and well-being; #4 Quality education]

1. Deep listening, Beholding, and resilience

- Introduction of deep listening to oneself and others for building resilience and self-care in classroom setting

[SDG-GE#3 Good Health and well-being; #4 Quality education]

1. Contemplative approaches to reading and writing

- Introduction of contemplative reading which requires quiet reflection, mindful attentiveness, and letting go of thoughts; contemplative writing requires self-exploration and expression in a quiet classroom setting

[SDG-GE#3 Good Health and well-being; #4 Quality education]

Part III – Contemplative education in social and global perspectives

Students will reflect critically on issues of equity, inclusion, and sustainability in community and global level with the knowledge of contemplation.

1. Equity, Inclusion, and Social awareness and Justice

- examination of issues of inequity in education system and society due to poverty and social inequality; discussion of possible solutions with knowledge of contemplation and social awareness

[#16 Peace, Justice and Strong Institutions]

1. Non-violent communication and establishing peaceful community

- Introduction of approaches and practices of non-violent communication in interpersonal communication for establishing a peaceful family and community

[#16 Peace, Justice and Strong Institutions]

1. Introspection, reflection, and global awareness

- Examination of social crises related to consumption and production in social and global perspectives; [#12 Responsible consumption and Production]

1. Contemplative practices and sustainability in global context

- Introduction of contemplative practices related to mindful consumption and production in social and global perspectives; [#12 Responsible consumption and Production]

courses.title: Educational Thought
courses.description: This course aims to discuss the prominent thoughts directing educational practice and their philosophical origins or foundations. Educational thoughts concerning the topics such as the meaning and aims of education, content and practice of teaching and learning will be introduced and examined in relation to various fields of philosophical investigation concerning knowledge and value, humanity and society, etc. Traditional and modern, Chinese and Western perspectives on education will be scrutinized.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Not for students majoring in programmes offered by Faculty of Education; not for CLED and ELED Majors; and students who have taken EDUC2220.
Co-requisite: UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or UGFN1001 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
courses.learning_outcomes:
The course aims to discuss the prominent thoughts directing educational practice and their philosophical origins or foundations. Besides, it also aims to enhance students' thinking about education by initiating them into philosophically informed educational thoughts, thereby acquiring the mechanism of 'resourcing' oneself within 'the virtuous circle of the enhancement of thinking and the enrichment of thought' (強化思考與深化思想的良性循環中得以開源成泉). After examining some basic educational concepts and ideals concerning the nature and values of education, the course will focus on aims of education as embedded in the educational practice of cultivating desirable human qualities in educated persons, moving from general themes (in Part 1) to special themes (in Part 2), built-in with a series of workshops on thinking through reading and writing「讀寫進思工作坊」**'RAW** Thinking Workshop' based on 'CAROL' method (employing the ACCESS approach for thinking 「六維四體進思法」developed by Roger Cheng).

Students are expected to:

(1)Be able to thoughtfully think about how to tackle three fundamental questions concerning the nature, values and aims of education: (a) what is education? (b) why is education desirable or valuable? (c) how is education is to be practised (concerning its aims, stages and dimensions)? Answering these questions is expected to draw on educational perspectives to be known as in (2).

(2)Be able to master substantive knowledge concerning four philosophically informed educational perspectives as possible answers to the above three questions: (a) 'fivefold education' for the whole person currently discussed in Hong Kong (五育觀、全人教育觀) ; (b) 'perfectionist education' advocated by Wang Kuowei (王國維之完人教育觀) as representing the modem presentation of the traditional Chinese educational thought; (c) the ideal of education for 'autonomy' advocated by the modem West, especially liberalism (自由教育觀); (d) 'quality-based education' (品育觀)-- education as the cultivation of desirable human qualities (SAVE: attitudes-virtues as qualities of hearts 心性;skills-excellences as qualities of powers 才力) based on the neo-Aristotelian perspective in relation to quality education (素質教育) advocated in the mainland China.

(3)Be interested in and be able to think thoughtfully about at least one of the five special dimensions of the 'whole person education' with a sufficient philosophical depth: (a) intellectual education; (b) moral education; (c) social education; (d) aesthetic education; and (e) spiritual education, in relation to the substantive knowledge on educational perspectives as well as their own educational experiences (at home, in school and/or in the university).

(4)Be ready to tryto pursue their own lines of thinking with the assistance of the 'CAROL' criteria embodied in the course of learning (including lectures and workshops) and assessment (mid term workshop serves for both 50% summative and formative assessments). Thus, they are encouraged to present their thoughts according to the 'CAROL' method of five criteria: **(A)** to articulate how problems of education (general problems concerning nature, values and aims of education based on certain educational perspectives, or special problems about dimensions of education) could be (C) critically discussed in drawing from (L) lectures and (R) required readings and (O) one's own thinking and experience.

courses.subject: UGED
courses.title: Understanding Human Rights
courses.description:
(UGED2700 is double-coded with GPAD2300.)

This course is to expose students to the field of human rights as a cross-disciplinary sub-discipline in law and political science. This course will assist students to better understand the debate concerning human rights both at home and abroad. The course will cover the international law and political issues in this field, the application of human rights in the domestic context and major problems in international human rights practice, including, for example, questions of gender discrimination, humanitarian intervention in domestic conflicts, poverty and human rights, and questions of universalism and cultural relativism.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
UGED2700 is double-coded with GPAD2300. 
Not for GPAD, LLB Majors, Double Degree of BBA and JD (BAJD); and students who have taken GPAD2300.
Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
courses.learning_outcomes:
The course would like to achieve the following outcomes:

1. To introduce the broad contours of human rights law and concepts and the goals and practices of the human rights movement

2. To engage the central debates that underlie the human rights movement and explore the implications of such debates in discrete areas of human rights law

3. To assist students in exploring their own interests in the field and in developing and achieving their own realistic goals for the study of human rights.
courses.course_syllabus:
I. Introduction-What is the Human Rights Movement About?

II. International Law-A Foundation for Human Rights

A. Customary Law

B. General Principles

C. Treaties

D. Nuremberg Trial-An Historical Foundation for Human Rights

E. Perspectives on International Law

F. State Sovereignty and Human Rights

G. Natural Rights and Human Rights

III. Civil and Political Rights

A. UN Foundations-Charter, Universal Declaration and ICCPR

B. Enforcement Under the ICCPR-A Prototype

1. Basic Powers and Functions

2. Comparison with Other Human Rights Treaties

C. State Duties Respecting Rights

D. The Public-Private Distinction

E. Human Rights Resolutions and Customary Practice

IV. Social and Economic Justice-Human Rights for the Poor?

A. Historical and Theoretical Context

B. Relating the Two Sets of Rights

C. Justiciability and Domestic Enforcement

D. International Monitoring

E. The Right to Development

V. Human Rights and Culture -Are Human Rights Just Western?

A. The Roots and Foundations of Human Rights

B. The Competing Claim for Human Responsibilities

C. Universalism Versus Cultural Relativism

The East Asian Perspective

D. Cultural Wars: Gender, Religion and Children

1. Inequality for Women

2. International Standards and the Women's Convention (CEDAW)

3. Gender and Culture

4. Religion and Human Rights

5. The Rights of Children

VI. The UN Human Rights System

A. Basic Concepts and Structures

B. The Historic UN Commission on HR-Special Procedures

courses.description: Different values and beliefs, opposing clinical objectives, and resource limitations are persistent issues in medical and healthcare settings, from which ethical dilemmas could arise among healthcare practitioners, patients, and their family members, who are unavoidably engaged in the decision-making process in difficult health, life, and death scenarios. These scenarios may include but are not limited to organ donation, resuscitation of a terminally ill loved one, withdrawing or withholding life-sustaining and standard curative treatments for an end-of-life patient, active euthanasia and physician-assisted suicide, as well as healthcare rationing. While a well-established legal and health system can provide guidelines for walking through these processes, the values and beliefs of the patients, healthcare workers, and other decision-makers (including family members and guardians) would shape the way decisions are made. Therefore, understanding the factors that may shape or influence one’s values and moral beliefs is crucial for any meaningful discussions to resolve these dilemmas. This course will use a systematic approach to guide students in understanding the moral theories and principles pertinent to the works of bioethics, identifying the morally salient features and arguments of selected clinical, healthcare, and health-related scenarios, discussing and analyzing the main bioethical issues of those scenarios, as well as describing ways to resolve the relevant moral dilemma. Students will be introduced to different simulation exercises and scenarios to realize and reflect on the factors that shape their own decisions as well as moral values and beliefs. The course will utilize lectures, tutorials, case studies, and sharing of hands-on experience to guide students in adopting an all-rounded, holistic, and perspective-based approach to discuss and resolve the bioethical dilemmas related to health, life, and death matters.

Not for Biomedical Sciences; Public Health majors; and students who have taken PHPC3012. 
Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
courses.course_syllabus:
* *1.** **Bioethics and moral status: What makes living organisms possess moral status?** The basis of moral status, and why human beings are considered to possess moral status form the foundation of the study of bioethics. As human beings are agreed to possess full moral status, this introductory lecture will engage students in a reflection on what humans are by nature, and how human is viewed from the moral perspective, i.e. what are the specific human features that ground human moral status.

* *2.** **Moral theories: Consequentialist utilitarianism** (the consequence of an action e.g. the number of lives that matters most morally) **vs. Categorical deontology** (the universal principle of the duty of the action itself that matters more morally) using classic trolleyology as example: what matters more? The strengths and limitations of the two main traditional moral theories.

* *3. Moral theories: Principlism.** Recognize the origin of the 4 pillars of principlism. Identify the bioethical issues and features of scenarios in the medical and healthcare settings. Learn the principlist method to resolve the moral dilemmas identified among the four principles in different scenarios. Recognize the deficiency and limitations of principlism in resolving moral dilemmas - why principlism necessary but inadequate in addressing the dilemma of life and death issues in the public health and healthcare settings. (e.g. Who to save? Decision-making under limited healthcare resources.Treat or not treat? Life-sustaining and standard curative treatments for end-of-life and terminally ill patients.)

* *4. Real life bioethical scenarios in Hong Kong and around the world.** Start a conversation: the pressing healthcare-related issues in Hong Kong (end-of-life care, organ donation, advanced therapies, Hong Kong Genome Project). Present some landmark and relevant local and international cases of bioethics in clinical and healthcare settings. Illustrate and analyze the moral dilemma and their respective bioethical arguments. Describe means of resolution of these conflicts.

* *5. Moral theories: Virtue ethics and character development.** From social psychology to bioethics: Milgrim Experiment. Does virtue exist in human beings or is it relative? Is pursuing virtue a meaningful project for human beings? Does character matter in bioethics? Describe the relevance of virtue and character to bioethics, power imbalance and coercion, bioethics in experiments and clinical trials (e.g. new drugs for a terminally ill patient), the importance of informed consent and the right to withdraw.

* *6.** **Beyond reasons in bioethics: Emotions, intuitions, experience, and relationships.** Hume’s Sentimentalism as a moral theory (is moral decision governed by emotion or reason more?). How sentimentalism, intuition, experience and relationships influence decision-making in bioethics and healthcare settings. Who to save? Should relationship and feelings matter? Reviewing “The Imitation Game” scenario. Case discussion: organ transplant, resuscitation of terminally ill loved ones/family members, body donation.

* *7. Beyond traditional moral theories in bioethics: Non-Western, religion, care, narrative, and feminist ethics.** Non-Western ethics: a summary of how Confucianism or other non-Western ethics (e.g. African bioethics) approach bioethical issues. Medical care against cultural or religious beliefs (Jehovah witness, non-therapeutic infant male circumcision). Care ethics: Case-based perspective vs principle-based perspective. Narrative ethics: An alternative but necessary method to bring particularity and lived experience into bioethics. Feminist ethics: is ethics gendered? How does feminist perspective contribute to understanding the pluralism of bioethics?

* *8. Living in a pluralistic world of bioethics: Perspectives vs foundational approach to bioethics.** Monism vs. Pluralism: why we need to approach bioethics in a pluralistic manner? The limitations of monistic approach to bioethics. Why and how we should approach bioethics using different perspectives and lenses.

* *Tutorials:**

* *1.** **Decision-making in healthcare settings (with simulation exercise):** An introduction to how the principles of respect for autonomy, non-maleficence, beneficence and justice are relevant and featured in healthcare scenarios. Identify the moral dilemmas in the scenarios, and reflect on the rationale behind the decisions.

* *2. Moral decision-making of life and death matters (with simulation exercise to inform AI decision making):** Moral Machine Exercise of Automated Car. Identify and reflect on feelings, sentiments as well as reasoning that go into the decision-making process. Recognize personal values and what shape one’s moral decision regarding life and death matters.

* *3. Case study: Bringing it all together:** Use case study to illustrate how a pluralistic approach to bioethics works.

* *Glossary/Notes:**

* **Care ethics:** How about the genuine care and concerns for other people and living beings?
* **Feminist ethics:** Can we treat the moral theories available not as foundations but different perspectives?
* **Minority ethics:** What about the moral concerns of the minority?
* **Narrative ethics:** How about the stories and experiences behind people’s decisions?
* **Principlism:** Moral theories that are based on one single principle seems to be too narrow… how about one that has four?
* **Trolleyology:** stems from the “trolley problem” or “trolley dilemma” invented by the contemporary British philosopher Phillipa Foot in defending the doctrine of double effect (the morality of killing to save the life of others). Trolleyology is an evolved version of the trolley problem with scenarios that trigger different moral considerations behind judgment and a chosen action.
* **Virtue ethics:** Is it the act or the character of the person who does the act that counts morally?

courses.title: Freedom and Destiny
courses.description: Humans always hope for freedom. But we are finite beings. Most of what happens to us is beyond our control and decision. Is our will free? Is life determined? In what sense can we make a free choice? What can and what should we do in the face of destiny? This course will deal with these significant problems and the tension between freedom and destiny, in order to stimulate students’ reflection on their own lives.

courses.subject: UGED
courses.title: Humanity and Nature in Crisis: Values, Lifeways, and the Future
courses.description:
This course asks what we should value in nature (Units 1 and 2), how we should live with respect to it (Unit 3), and what future we should imagine for humanity and the planet (Unit 4). In Unit 1, we orient ourselves in our current situation: the Anthropocene, the planetary period in which a single species, human beings, has become the dominant force shaping the present and future of the planet. We also acquire some core theoretical tools for investigating what we value and how we should live. In Unit 2, we ask what, if anything, we should care about beyond our fellow human beings. Should we care about animals, plants, and ecosystems, and how should we act towards them? In Unit 3, we turn to various complementary disciplines across the humanities and social sciences to explore how humans might live differently within and towards the nonhuman natural world. In Unit 4, we turn to questions of the future, asking what kind of world we should imagine and seek to bring about for humanity and nonhuman life, on planet Earth and beyond. Where relevant, we will explore these topics through regional and local examples.

This course bears on several of the United Nations’ Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). We will see how work in the humanities and arts can motivate climate action (SDG#13 Climate Action). By reimagining our relationship with the environment and the connections between nature and culture, we can envision more sustainable ways of life in a heavily urbanized space like Hong Kong (SDG#11 Sustainable Cities and Communities). And by transforming our attitude towards and relationship with nature, we enjoy the mental health benefits of a deepened appreciation of and connection with nature (SDG#3 Good Health and Well-Being). With its special focus on environmental issues in Hong Kong, this course also addresses conservation concerns for Life Below Water (SDG#14) and Life On Land (SDG#15). The humanities and arts provide an alternative lens through which to understand today’s economic, social, and environmental problems, and the needs of those affected by climate change.

courses.title: Philosophy of Travel
courses.description: This course examines the philosophical reflection on travel in both Chinese and Western culture. It will provide students with a good understanding of the multifaceted relationships between travel and human existence from an interdisciplinary perspective. What make us go? How the travel or tourist experiences have been constructed? Topics to be discussed include: different forms of travel throughout history; mobility and the dynamics of space and time; the death of distance and the end of travel; nomad philosophy and the meaning of travel in the post-modern world.

courses.title: Death and Immortality
courses.description: This course aims at an interdisciplinary study of the problem of death and immortality. The ideas of death and the arguments for and against the possibility of life after death in both Chinese and Western culture will be examined from the religious, psychological, and philosophical perspectives. Classical and modern theories on this topic will be discussed. The purpose of this course is to examine the meaning of life from a theoretical reflection on its apparent opposite—death, thus enhancing students' ability to think critically about life and death.

courses.title: Inter/Transdisciplinary Research and Environmental Art Co-Creation
courses.description:
The course is designed to immerse students in a unique experiential learning journey to understand sustainability from both scientific and artistic perspectives, emphasizing active engagement and co-creation in tackling environmental challenges. We use the United Nations' Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) as a foundational framework, encouraging students to take personal responsibility for planetary wellbeing.

The knowledge delivery structure unfolds in three main segments—Theories, Tools, and Studio/Lab—beginning with the students' own environmental inquiries. Collectively, we seek answers through these segments. Each segment builds on the previous one, deepening understanding, developing interdisciplinary skills for dissecting global challenges, and facilitating collaborative art projects. We aim to translate ecological research, environmental education into moving and impactful narratives that could inspire change and foster guardianship for Earth’s future.

Co-requisite: Any course with "UGFH" or "UGFN" as prefix (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)

courses.learning_outcomes:
After taking the course, students will:

1. Develop a basic understanding of the UN's Sustainable Development Goals through hands-on artistic projects using mixed media such as drawing, video, sound, installation, etc.

2. Utilize interdisciplinary methodologies to research complex environmental issues.

3. Translate theoretical frameworks into self-directed actionable projects, using creative approaches

4. Be able to collaborate with diverse stakeholders, community partners, experts, and policy-makers to advocate for initiatives promoting planetary wellbeing.
courses.course_syllabus:
* *Week 1-2: Introduction to SDG and the Anthropocene Epoch**

Theories: Anthropocene and Sustainability

During the initial two weeks of the course, the focus will be on introducing the students with the UN’s Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) and the concept of the Anthropocene Epoch. These topics will be thoroughly explored from a wide range of disciplinary perspectives, ensuring a fundamental understanding.

SDG-9 Industry, Innovation and Infrastructure

SDG-11 Sustainable Cities and Communities

* *Week 3-4: Inter/Transdisciplinary Practices**

During Week 3, the course focuses on transdisciplinary approaches in defining and evaluating the social, economic, and ecological pillars of sustainability, reviewing practical tools within theoretical studies. Week 4 introduces "Design Thinking: Trans-Species Wellbeing (Empathy) Mapping Studio," emphasizing design thinking in addressing complex ‘wicked problems’ real-life settings. Students develop creativity, empathy, and prototyping skills through interviewing, ideation, and rapid prototyping exercises. This week's focus is on designing human-centered solutions while considering the needs of diverse ecosystems such as soil, ocean, air, and forests.

* *Week 5-6 Environmental Art Case Studies**

In Weeks 5-6, students will explore the diverse nature of environmental art and understand its significance in promoting critical thinking and dialogue about sustainability. They will learn how environmental art serves as a catalyst for turning ecological awareness into tangible action. The curriculum will cover the influence of artivism and eco-media on community engagement, awareness, and transformative action. Students will analyze case studies highlighting how artists collaborate with various stakeholders to tackle environmental challenges and the crucial components that contribute to the success of community-driven campaigns.

Mid-term interdisciplinary research presentation about students’ plan for Common Good Project.

* *4 Studio Sessions within CUHK Farm, Forest, Marine Lab, Air Quality Monitoring Centre at PGE Station**

* *Week 7 Studio Soil: Sowing Seeds of Change with Relational Aesthetics**

- - SDG Life on Land at CUHK farm

Session focus: Art, Science, and Farming Converge to Tackle Food System Challenges

In the soil session, students will examine the complex issues plaguing our food systems, such as climate change, biodiversity loss, and the pursuit of fair nutrition and farmer welfare. Students will do a short video piece on the farm or interview local farmers to learn about community shared agriculture.

* *Week 8 Studio Air: Toxic Cloud, CO2, and Impressionism**

SDG Target 3.9.1 - calls for a substantial reduction in deaths and illnesses from air pollution.

Session Focus: Intersection of Art and Atmospheric Science in the Context of Industrialization's Impact on Air Quality at CUHK’s Air Quality Monitoring Centre at the PGE Station

The air session of the course explores the intersection of art and atmospheric science in the context of industrialization's impact on air quality, as evidenced in 19th-century artworks like those of J.M.W. Turner. The analysis of nearly 130 paintings by climate physicist Anna Lea Albright, in collaboration with climatologist Peter Huybers, reveals a correlation between rising coal use, sulfur dioxide emissions, and a visible decline in air quality, reflected in the reduced contrast and white-hued shift of the paintings. Drawing workshop will be conducted in the Air Quality Monitoring Centre at the PGE Station after a brief introduction of how artists dealt with the theme of atmospheric pollution, pantone color grey and how scientists monitor air qualities in Hong Kong.

* *Week 9 Studio Forest: The Whispering or the Roaring from the Wilderness**

SDG 13 – Climate Action at CUHK forest

Session Focus: The Synergy of Sound Art and Environmental Activism in Forest Conservation

In this session, students will juxtapose the immersive sound art of Janet Cardiff and George Bures Miller's "FOREST (for a thousand years…)" with an environmental activism in Germany's Dannenröder forest led by Dr. Bente Castro Campos. Students will engage in a collaborative sound mapping exercise. They will venture into the nearby forest, equipped with recording devices, to capture the diverse acoustic signatures of the natural environment.

* *Week 10 Studio Ocean: Creative Service for Extreme Aqua Circumstances**

Studio session at Marine Lab

SDG 14- Life Below Water

Session focus: Deep time manifested by art, science, and conservation in the ocean

In our ocean session, students will dive into the pressing concerns surrounding ocean warming, drawing inspiration from Susan Schuppli's thought-provoking work "Learning from Ice" and Jason deCaires Taylor's mesmerizing underwater sculptures. By examining the interplay between media art, marine science, and the Earth's deep time revealed by the depth of our oceans, students will explore how 'evidentiary aesthetics' can contribute to novel ways of scientific understanding and innovate new forms of knowledge. Students will aspire to create artwork that transcends mere representations of nature's beauty, instead taking an active role in documenting, restoring, and preserving marine habitats, thereby becoming agents of change in the face of environmental challenges, a process through which they will develop and demonstrate their know-how in their final co-creation projects.

* *Week 11-12: THE COMMON GOOD PROJECT Development**

Each group will have 2 weeks to situate themselves to work with their chosen community, or collaborate with an artist's studio or a scientist's research laboratory. Students are required to regularly check-in and have interactive tutorials with their instructors, technical support team and/or science advisers (optional) to guide them through their co-creation process.

* *Week 13: THE COMMON GOOD PROJECT- Public Salon and Presentation**

SDG 17 - Strengthen the means of implementation and revitalize the global partnership for sustainable development

Students will present their final COMMON GOOD project, synthesizing their discoveries in the art and science of sustainability and co-creation, to a public audience composed of members from the scientific and artistic communities, environmental NGO partners, and peers. They will discuss the extent to which their group has successfully addressed the inquiries they brought into the course at the beginning of the semester, reflecting on their experiential learning journey and personal growth in embracing environmental stewardship.

courses.title: Philosophy, Film and Life
courses.description:
The course aims to explore aspects of human life as reflected in philosophy and film. It introduces aesthetic concepts, film languages, and different schools and styles of film-making. It also explores the philosophical implications of films. Through selected films, students will be encouraged to develop critical thinking skills and concern for the meaning of life. Discussion will focus on three categories:
(1) films concerning humanities: the nobleness and darkness of human nature, the joy and sadness of love, and the absurdity of life; (2) films concerning virtual reality: the implications of the emulated world in sci-fi films, self-consciousness, and the crisis of false memory; (3) the metaphysical significance in films: the image of death, the origin of holiness and evil, and theism versus atheism.

courses.description: The course aims to introduce to students conceptions and misconceptions about sign language and deaf community. Crucially it explores how deaf and hearing people perceive sign language and deafness and how such perceptions from the hearing and deaf communities might lead to ideological conflicts in the preservation of socio-cultural values of the deaf community and its language, in the methodology and technology of speech and language rehabilitation, and in the mode of deaf education. The course will address these conflicting ideologies from the perspectives of linguistics, sociology, cultural studies, psychology, medicine and education.

courses.subject: UGED
courses.title: Reflections on Everyday Life
courses.description:
This course provides an opportunity for students to reflect on the formation of "self" in society and how the society affects our understanding of love, consumption, education, work, and meaning of life. Selected references in sociology, psychology, religion and literature will be introduced to provide a board intellectual perspective to understand the complex relationships between self and society. Students are expected to acquire an ability to analyze and critique on how different social institutions such as education, religion, family, media, work, consumerism, state, etc., affect our attitude and behaviors in some essential issues of life such as mate choice. Following the tradition of critical theory, this course assumes that this reflection is the first step for liberating from "bad faith" and living an authentic life.

Through reflection on experience that affects them most, students are encouraged to critically examine sustainability issues concerning the well-beings of young people (topic 1, 2, 3 and SDG3), quality of education (topic 4 and SDG4), sustainability in the workplace (topic 5 and SDG8) and inequalities in the local context (topic 3, 4, 5 and SDG10).

courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Critical mind – to look some distance beyond the commonly accepted or officially defined goals of human actions.
2. Good observation – the ability to grasp the relationship between our individual lives and the larger social forces that help to shape them.
3. Ability to read books and apply knowledge.
4. To comprehend the interconnectedness of everyday life and selected sustainability issues, such as wellbeing, education, work and inequality (SDG3, 4, 8, 10).
courses.course_syllabus:
Fundamental Concepts

Social control, social norms, self, role, socialization, internalization, interpretation, definition of situation, world-taken-for-granted, ideology, bad faith, dependence, conformity, sense of security, freedom, autonomy, spontaneity.

Selected topics

1. Self and Society – discusses the “bad faith” and possibility of freedom in everyday life; and the “presentation of self”. Major concepts introduced: social control, social norms, self, role, socialization, internalization, interpretation, definition of situation, world-taken-for-granted, ideology, bad faith, dependence, conformity, sense of security, freedom, autonomy.

1. Love in a Commercialized World – discusses the rise of romantic love and the deceptive nature of erotic love, the making of the “modern traditional” family illustrated by the case of wedding; and how the commercialized world and the individualization process in post-industrial society further erode the “art of loving”. Major concepts introduced: self, role, dependence, sense of security, individualization, capitalism, modernity, post-modernity.

1. Digital Selves in the Online World – discusses the making and presentation of multiple selves since the digital revolution and consumer society; has the “one dimensional man” turned to be a genuine individual in the internet or becoming more monotonous and “one dimensional”? Major concepts: digital age, consumer society, freedom, autonomy, spontaneity, resistance, selves.

1. The Social Construction of Childhood and Modern Education – discusses the “discovery of childhood” and the emergence of the “priceless child” in the capitalist economy. Major concepts: socialization, parenting, value of education and learning.

1. Work and Corrosion of Character and Emotion – discusses how the “flexible regime” of work in new capitalism impacts on the formulation of character, the meaning of life, and the trust in community; and how deep-acting in service sector damages people’s emotional capacity. Major concepts introduced: self, role, socialization, internalization, character, emotional labor, decline of career.

1. Meaning of Life in Late-Modernity – discusses how different cultures and societies define the meaning of life. Major concepts introduced: self, role, socialization, internalization, spontaneity, self-actualization, making sense of life.

(UGED2980 is double-coded with ANTH2350.)

In societies across the world, people have different culturally-shaped senses of what their lives mean: people may live for money, love, honour or fame; for family, company, country or religion. This course examines the processes through which meanings of life are formulated and maintained in day-to-day life in societies past and present; it also explores life meaning as a way of comprehending the evolution of human societies. The course uses the concept of "meanings of life" as a window into the anthropological understanding of cultural difference and cultural evolution.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
UGED2980 is double-coded with ANTH2350. 
Not for Anthropology Majors; and students who have taken ANTH2350.
Co-requisite: UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or UGFN1001 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
courses.learning_outcomes:
In this course, students learn about the processes through which individual meanings of life are formed and negotiated between individuals and their societies; they learn this through reading and analysis of individual life stories in different societies, and (optionally) through conducting and analyzing their own interviews. Students also learn about the evolution of senses of meaning across human history, from prehistory up until the present and future, in a range of different societies.

Taken together, these two areas of learning will enable students to think about human societies past and present, and about human lives lived within these societies, from a new perspective. In addition, it is expected that students will be able to think about their own lives and personal meanings in a deeper and broader and more conscious way; in this sense, although this course is academic, it transcends the purely academic, to have a potential impact on students' own thinking about how to

live their lives.

By the end of the course, students will be expected: a) to be able to think objectively, analytically and critically about meanings of life within their own and other societies, and understand the complex linkages between individuals and society in creating meaning, b) to be able to comprehend the broad panorama of the evolution of meaning over the course of human history, and c) (this objective, although discussed in class, is purposely left untouched by examinations) to be able to understand their own lives in a fuller and more insightful way.
